The PressjCen and tub Newsbots.— Preaching
at the Pil.t-street Congregational Church last
night, the Rev. E. -T. Duustan said he felt he
should be neglecting his duty if he did not make
a protest against the'action of certain represen-
tatives of the press last Sunday. Had he listened
to the dictates of expediency, or obeyed the voice of
inclination, he would have remained silent, but for
the second time certain "pressmen had outraged
the sentiment of the community by organising a
picnio for newsboys cn the Lord’s Day. The law
stood upon the Statute Books, and should, there-
fore, be obasrved. The pre&s exercised a power-
ful, moral, social, and political influence, and the
community had a right to look to it for carefu 1
guidance.

Yesterday bad been proclaimed by the Govern-
ment as a day of humiliation and prayer for rain,
but happily it was converted into a day of fhanks-
piving instead.
I Archbishop Smith had pi omulgated a form of prayer
' which was in consonance with the proclamation.
By the prayer it was contemplated that worsbip-
l pers should hntnble themselves before God
in this tboir “ time of special distress and
anxiety.” This really related to the condition of
things prior to the general fall of rain, and as it
I was considered that it did not correctly describe the
j condition of affairs now prevailing, some clergy-
men manifested a reluctance to use the form, and
relied upon the special prayer and thanksgiving
embraced in the ‘‘Book of Common Prayer.”
Some ministers used the special form of prayer ,
for rain issued by the Archbishop, others used
the ordinary form, and others again used
the thanksgiving. There were yet other I
ministers who, in acknowledgment of the
general rain, read the thanksgiving, and who,
having regard to the wants of those districts still in
need of rain, recited the ordinary prayer for rain.

THURSDAY, JUNE 15, 1911.
Pluck fin.
THE RUSH TO YASSBERRA.
In connection with the controversy over retaining’ Government House in Sydney, King O’Malley (Minister for Home Affairs) suggests that the G.-G. should campon the Federal
capital aite at Yassberra. “There would be beautiful fishing for him,” says the Minister. “ Moreover, he could drink of the waters of the Cotter the purest stream in the world.
There is no water like it. And he could have splendid shooting, too. No better in the world. He would have plenty of room for his horse. Also, he could so familiarise himself
with the territory that when he returned to England he would be able to expound to prospective Governors-General what a beautiful place it is, and what would be the prospects before
them when they got to Australia. I firmly believe that there would be a tremendous rush of applications for the position of King s representative in the Commonwealth. 1 his news
of the attractions of Yass-Canberra and the prospects of spending half the year now and as much of the year as they desire later at the Federal capital would spread through the
Empire. It would be magnificent.”

To the Editor of the Evenino News.
Sir, —As Dr. Thompson, chief of the Health
Department, has announced the disease of the
bubonic germs in rats, one thing is now certain,
that dogs and cats will become the chief vehicles
of transmission to man, not only because of their
disposition to hunt and kill rats, but also because
many of them feed on the dead rats, and because
dogB and cats are often found sniffing round rat-
holes and among straw where rats have been.
All fondling of dogs and cats should for the pre-
sent cease. Certainly, all children found nursing
and kissing cats and dogs should be reproved.
Very great cleanliness must now become the order
of the day. If the authorities established public
dog-baths, this would be much more beneficial
than chasing rats.
J Pottie, VS.

GOING BACK TO WORK; THE TOILER WHOSE CASE NO ONE CONSIDERS.
When the coal mines stopped working the horses were brought to the surface. Some of them then saw daylight for the first time in three years.
Many of these veterans went blind after a few days’ sunlight, and groped around miserably, breaking their legs in gullies, where they were some-
times found and mercifully shot, and sometimes left to die of thirst. Three of the parties interested in the coal strike—the miners, the mine-
owners and the consumers—have received a lot of notice. How about the fourth party ?

Mr. Frank R. Srockron.
A SOCIAL QUESTION.
Thera are carriages set
apart for ‘ ladies only,’ but
the other sex have to chance
their company. And that
this is no small risk has just
been proved by the incident
reported from. Tasmania,
where a lone man with a
pulmonary complaint found
himself the only fellow-
traveller of an hysterical girl.
As he was taking a dose of
cough-mixture her disordered
imagination smelt what she
thought was chloroform, and,
believing that ho meant to
drug her, she jumped out of
the train at the risk of her
life and laid a serious charge
•gainst him.”— Daily Paper.

“THE IMAGE VILE OF FRAUD.”
Lo, the tell monster with the deadly sting,
Who passes mountains, breaks through fenced walls
And firm embattled spears, and with his filth
Taints all the world!...
Forthwith that image vile of Fraud appear'd,
His face the semblance of a just man's wore,
So kind and gracious was its outward cheer;
The rest was serpent a 11....
As ofttimes a light skiff, moor'd to the shore,
Stands part in water, part upon the land.
Or, as where dwells the greedy German boor.
The beaver settles, watching for his prey,
So on the rim that fenced the sand with rock
Sat perch'd the fiend of evil.
Dante’s •• Inferno,” Canto XVII*

Tales of the Riverine.
“Dictionary Nod.”
(FOR THE BULLETIN.)
BY PRIUE WARUNG.
Emerson says soiu.e where that it is an
achievement of high eloquence to confer an ex-
pressive nick-name, but no particularly fine
ouality, oratorical or other, was needed to attach
n bye-name to Ned .
Ah— now I’m stuck ! It has never dawned
upon me till this moment that in all the years
t liat I knew Ned to bo spoken of, I never heard
his surname once. Perhaps none of the men who
referred to him constantly as one of the biggest
“cures” in that region of “cures” and “queer
cards,” the Riverine district —where each square
mile has its tale of some human soul going to
wreck in its sea of grey plain—knew his surname.
Perhaps he hadn’t one to know. Most likely,
indeed, was this the case. His earliest recollection
went back to the time when he was tending
Parson Marsden’s black poleys on the venerable
Principal Chaplain’s grant at Bathurst, so, as
likely as not, Ned was one of the hundreds of
infants that were cradled in Parramatta Factory
and sent into the world worse than motherless and
with a choice among 50 fathers. At all events, I
am pretty sure none of the fellows who spoke of
y ß d to me knew his surname. Else it must
have slipped out sometimes. But it was always
‘•Dictionary Ned.”
Xow I was saying that anybody without the
faintest touch of eloquence could have given Ned
tliat name—would iiave conferred no other upon
il,im had the selection of a hundred appellations
been offered. Even a Victorian shire-councillor,
who is the least oratorical person in existence,
except when he wants a railway to his front gate,
would have called him “ Dictionary Ned.” The
cjngruity of the term was so obvious that a blind
man could have seen it.
The name had its origin in the fact that Ned
always carried a dictionary-a wonderful sort of
one. It was based “ upon the labours of Johnson,
Worcester, Webster,” and Heaven knows how
many more, “ and incorporated the latest results
uf the most modern and scientific Lexico-
graphers.” Further, it was illustrated by “ one
thousand Superb Engravings from drawings by the
Best Artists’ (I am quoting from the title page)
—and as though that was not enough to furnish
to the humble student, it supplied, at the fore-
part, an “Analytical History of the Growth
of the English Language (in two pages), and, in
appendices, a ‘Glossary’ of Scientific Terms, a
Classical Encyclopedia, and a Collection of Pro-
verbial Sayings and Phrases from all Languages.”
The whole of this overflowing repository of learn-
ing had been published at sixpence; and Ned
paid ninepence for it on his solitary trip to
Melbourne at Cole’s bookstall in Paddy's Market,
in Bourke-street, 25 years ago. Cole wasn’t a
millionaire then, and you couldn’t buy books at
English prices. You paid ninepence for a sixpenny
publication, and fifteen-pence for a shilling one,
andhalf-a-crown, and sometimes three shillings, for
a two-shilling volume. And Ned, paying nine-
pence, had therewith purchased a treasure of
wealth untellable, of joys limitless. All the
glorious orbs in the firmament of culture swam
into his ken when he pocketed the book.
Keats never extracted from Chapman’s Homer,
Landor from Shakespeare, Lindsey Gordon from
Horace, Marcus Clarke from Balzac, one thou-
sandth part of the delight Ned obtained from his
dictionary. The only volume ho ever possessed, to
him it was a library, a literature, mauy-volumed
life itself. Somehow or other, the intangible
charm that the mere study of words as words, as
the fossils of human experience and emotion, has
for so many people, had entranced this illiterate
wanderer whose home was always on the fringe
of “settled country,” who was never at ease
except he was “ inside,” who got astray in a one
street township and was utterly lost in the soli-
tudes of a great city. Amongst the thousand
and one types of humanity that wandered
over the Old Man and One Tree Plains, there was
the man who never turned in till ho had read a
chapter out of his Bible, there was the man who
carried a shilling Shakespeare, and the other who
kept his mind alive on Byron, there was the fellow
who always kept a woman’s photograph, and the
one who nourished his soul amid deadening wastes
by the crucifix dangling round his neck. The
consolation that each and all derived from his and
their several idols, Ned drank in from his pocket-
dictionary.
lie had bought it with the vain hope of
making up the deficiencies of his early educa-
tion. “Never too late to larn, boys,” he would
assure the scoffers. And though he was wise in
the wondrous lore of the plains and the rive s, “up
to any dodge ” in free-selection and station-life,
knew every trick of bush-craft and of river-craft,
had overlanded cattle in the early gold days from
Adelaide to Forest Creek, and (earlier still) sheep
from Bathurst to the valley of the Wannon in far
western “ Port Phillip,” and had held the wheel
of the Lady Augusta when she ran up to Tocum-
wal months before Cadell made his first chart of
the Murray, he esteemed his precious knowledge,
out of which so many “smarter” men had coined
small fortunes, to be worthless compared with
“book-laming.” At every interval of leisure,
and during the times of work when the duty of
the moment would not be impeded by “study,”
out would come his book. When other men
smoked or swopped yarns, or drank, Ned studied.
There was nothing complex about his methods.
1 le went straight at the business of mastering its
contents.
Somewhere about forty years of age when he
invested his ninepence, by the time he became
bargeman of the Royal Duke barge—she was built
in the epoch when ferocious “loyalty” dislocated
a man’s neck as consort of the Currency La>s
steamer, he was within a year or two of fifty. And
unremitting in his pursuit of knowledge with all
sorts of difficulties, he had mastered the dictionary
so far as “ V,” the page that begins with “ vital ”
and ends with “ votive.” Ten words a day for a
minimum, and a hundred for a maximum—when
he had a rare holiday he totted up the hundred —
he had got off by rote the words and their mean-
ings. And this was without counting the
Sundays. He had devoted those to the “ Glossary”
and the, “ Proverbial Sayings and Phrases,’ and
to the horrible combination of letters which Ih >
dictionary-compiler, on the authority of the
modern and scientific lexicographer, used to
express the pronunciation of the foreign phrases.
It was a gigantic task this last, and Ned had done
well to devote his Sabbaths to it when he had no
other occupation than to boil his white shirt for
the next Sunday. Mezzofanti himself would have
felt the task of memorising the phrases to be
herculean if lie had also found it necessary to
recjlh-et the kev to their pronunciation. .lust
think of the labour of getting off by heart not
merely the interpretation, for instance, of
L’homme propose el Dieu dispose, but the weird
and mysterious conjunction of letters which the
latest modern and scientific lexicographer
expressed the sound of the phrase: “lom-pro-a-
dyoo-dis-poz.” But all these fearful and wonder-
ful shibboleths were gradually being mastered by
Ned—to an accent, lie was a beggar to learn,
was Ned. As he himself said, “he warn’t no
slouch at stickin’ to it.”
That was the curious thing about Ned. All Ins
grinding away at vocabularies never seemed to
tinge by the faintest degree of refined colour his
vigorous colloqualism. Perhaps, in some distaiit
period, when he contemplated sitting under his
own vine and fig-tree —the most errant knight of
the Murrumbidgee plains has always a vision of
some roof-tree o’ his ain—he intended to employ
his “dictionary words,” but in the days of his
scholarship he kept to the rude, energetic speech
of his kind.
Nor was it clear why he hadn’t begun “laming”
before he reached middle-age. Once he was
interrogated upon the point, but the answer,
though apparently at the moment conclusive, does
not appear a sufficient explanation now that we
can look back.
11.
It was in the following circumstances that the
question was put to him, and the answer re-
ceived. Ned was running shares in a fencing
contract on Benduck at the ’Bidgee. Sunday
came, and Ned, having washed and ironed the
white shirt he had worn at intervals during the
week in readiness for the succeeding Sunday,
donned his other “ b’iled rag ” and the moleskins
which lie called his “ go-to-meetln’s,” though they
never went there. His toilette operations weie
observed with keen interest by one of the fellows
who had sundowned it to the men’s hut the
previous night in the expectation of the plum-duff
and lot of rum which Benduck, even more liberal
than other stations, invariably gave to the Satur-
day to Monday “whalers.” A man of middle
height and naturally sturdy frame, already, while
still young, he carried himself with the swagman’s
stoop, and his watery eyes gave the lie to the story
of natural or acquired refinement which the clear-
cut features would have otherwise told. Dirty
with the indescribable dirt of the man of position
who is debased to a congenial gutter, College Bill
revolted, as he lay on a sheepskin in the early sun-
shine, against Ned’s sacrifice at the altar of clean-
“ Who’s that toff ? ” he asked of the cook.
“bin? W’y, that’s Dic-shun-cry Ned ! Never
’erd of ’im ? ”
“ That Dictionary Ned ! My word, I didn't
know he went in for white shirts and collars ! I’ll
have some fun with him, boys—just you come and
watch ! ” .
Now, College Bill was esteemed a bit of a
humourist, or rather of a satirist. For a “Bishop
Barker” he would compose a quatrain on any
subject—a person preferred—suggested by the man
who tipped him the drink, ana for a bottle of
brandy he would write a fifty-line satire and recite
it with becoming action. It was whispered among
the bosses and “colonial-experiencers ” that he
was a University prize poem man, but that could
hardly be so, for Bill’s “Ode to Swipes,” the
shanty-keeper at One Tree, was quoted all over the
Riverine for its originality and force, and since
the first University was, there has never been a
prize-poem which contained these qualities.
Being what he was. Bill always had a claque,
and when he meandered his odorous carcase to the
tank side, where Ned was performing his toilette,
lie was followed by several others of the sundown-
ing brotherhood prepared in advance to applaud
his satirical efforts at old Dictionary’s expense.
They were already in laughter by the time they
had covered half the distance between the hut and
the tank, for Bill, as ho walked, improvised—
Devoted student! while other “ whalers” slumber
He studies hard, does Dictionary Ned !
But still he’s storing only useless lumber
In the squash pumpkin which he calls his head 1
“You’re Dictionary Ned, arn’t you?” began
Bill, as he approached. “I’m Bill College
Bill, the boys call me. Shake !”
Ned turned at the remark. Perhaps it was the
circumstance that his fingers were busy buttoning
his collar—he had only the one collar—that pre-
vented him accepting Bill’s preferred hand. Any-
how, he did not take it. He simply nodded and
said :
“Oh, yer Bill, are yer ?—College Bill? I’ve
hern o’ yer 1”
“Yes,” responded Bill, not feeling quite so easy
as he should, his reception was so chilling, “ no
doubt you have. Being brother students, y’
know ” —he paused to wink impressively at his
admirers —“ we ought to be acquainted 1”
“Ye-es —yer think so?” drawled Ned.
‘ ‘ Of course. Men of culture are not too numerous
on the river country.”
“So?”
There was a titter, not quite at Ned’s expense.
Bill was annoyed at it, and grew truculent.
“ Do you know 1 think you should drop the
‘ Ned,’ my friend.”
“Yes?”
“ You should style yourself ‘Dick.’ ‘Dictionary
Dick ’ would be not only alliterative, but would
be more euphonious !” The chorus of laughter
again went up—now on Bill’s side. Wasn’t Bill
rubbing it in ! What jaw-breakers lie could use !
Ned didn't reply, but withdrew his dictionary
from the hip-pocket where he always carried it.
“ Going to look up ‘ alliterative ’ and
‘euphonious,’ old chap?” Bill continued. “Now
don’t turn up ‘ H —you’ll find the first under ‘A,’
and ‘euphonious’ under ‘E.’” And the rouse-
abouts and swagmen grew merrier. Bill was
getting on well with his chiacking of old Ned !
Ned, however, was still silent.
“Ned,” went on Bill, “ the only two men I ever
heard of that were books in breeches were
Macaulay and yourself. Macaulay was a beggar
to talk, but you’re a beggar to keep your mouth
shut. Oh, and by-the-way, why didn’t you take
your schooling earlier ?”
“ I don’t usu’lly ring my clapper on’y when I’ve
got some toon to play,” now responded Ned.
“ That answers yer first remark. An’, as ter the
second, it’s my turn ter ask questions. Yer can
read French, Mister Bill Boozer—l beg parding—
I mean. Mister College Bill ?”
Over his drunkard’s rosiness, Bill’s face showed
a deeper red. And the audience rejoiced exceed-
ingly. “Who’d ’a thought as ol’ Dicshunery
war goin’ ter take down College Bill ?”
“Can you read French, Mister? I’ve hear say
that yer ses as yer could. An’ if yer can, jest rip
out that for th’ pres’nt comp’ny 1” He held out
in one hand the dictionary open at the “Appendix
of Foreign Phrases,” and with his other fore-
finger pointed out the phrases wdiich he wished
interpreted. Bill stared, and the carmine of his
dissoluteness and of his shame vanished together.
Grey-green, like the salt-bush scrub near by, was
his quivering face.
“Look y’ere, coves,” went on Ned. “He’s a
college chap, an’ can’t tell yer what tnau— mo,

THE BENEFACTOR.
In the course of an address on Socialism to a meeting of the Women’s Liberal League, at North Sydney, the other evening, Mrs. Osborne said that there were many different
kinds of Socialism but they were all alike, inasmuch as the object was to repress individuality and to increase the power of the State. The lecturer quoted Milton’s line: “To
disenthrone the King of Heaven, we war, if war we must,” in support of the theory that Satan was the first Socialist.— Newspaper Item.

FROM THE WOMEN’S LIBERAL LEAGUE THAT IT WAS YOU AS GOT MY WAGES RAISED.”

London, Saturday.—James Wray, of New bourn
Wales, and George Towns, the Hunter River sculler, both
competed in the Christmas handicap yesterday on the

the winner.

He that outlives this day and comes safe home
Will stand a-tiptoe when this day is nam’d.
He that shall live this day and see old age
Will yearly on the vigil feast his neighbors.
Old men forget; yet all shall be forgot,
But he’ll remember with advantages
What feats he did that day.
—Henry V of England at Agincourt, Pas de Calais, October 25, 1415-

MARRYING HIM TO THE WRONG WOMAN.
A remarkable incident occurred at a wedding ceremony in Ballarat on Wednesday afternoon. The celebrant mistook an elder lady who was present for-the bride,and put
the usual questions to her instead of. to the other. When the ring was about to be placed on her finger the bridegroom, observing the bride agitation said, "What is the matter,
my girl? Don’t you feel well?” and the bride timorously replied, “I think there must be some mistake.” Well, who is really marrying this man?" asked the clergyman.
“Please, sir, I am!” responded the youthful bride. —Daily Paper.
Mr. Wade started his campaign against the Referendum proposals last night. —Daily Paper.
THE BRIDEGROOM : “Here, what’s your game? That sour hobble-skirt isn’t the girl I’m marrying—it’s the other one.”

“Speaking at Northcote (Vic.) on Saturday evening, Mr. Anstey, M.L.A., said that he probably would not seek re-election. Since he became a member of Parliament he had earned
about twice as much as he originally did, and for the first time in his life found himself in debt. He attributed this to the large number of a ppeals from persons who seemed to think
that it was his duty as their representative to assist them financially, and the loans were not likely to be repaid." —Daily Paper.

The members of the Victorian Society of Bellringers
now in Sydney on a ringing tour, and who, as report'd,
recently a compliahed the task of ringing " Holt’s
celebrated ten-part pea! of Orandsire Triples ” ftt St.
'Philip’s Church in three hours tifiaen minutes, also re-
corded two peals of “ Grandsiro Minor ”at St. Mark’s,
Darling point one conducied’by Mr. Harry Adams,
and tbeotherby Mr. Jno. Beeohoy on Tuesday last, Uu
Thursday the team and their friends were entertained
by the St. Philip’s Society,
Mr. Mor on gave the fo*at of “ The l.end wo live in,"
and eulogised the freedom and liberty we enjoyed under
its laws. Speaking of bells, he said that “ scientific
change ringing ” was not a source of pleasure to nil,
but he was sure its ooponents were in a minority, and
that all who had the good of their adopted land
at heart would even put up with u little
inconvenience to hoar those chin es rung, re-
calling to many times and scenes of long ago.'
Mr, Whitton proposed “ Success to Bellringing,” and
hoped further successes would follow the one recently
achieved. Mr. W. Albinson, in responding, expressed
a hope that Sydney ring- rs would pui forth ai) iheir
energies, and that the m xi peal might ha rung by New
South Waies_ m-n. Mr. H. Adams then, in feeling
terms, gave "The health of St. Philip’s society.”
coupled with the name of their conductor, Mr, John
Dennis, and said that ibis visit wopld be over remem-
bered by himself and brother ringers, not only as a red-
letter day in the annals of colonial iluging, but lor tbo
hearty wefl-ome that had been extenoed 10 them, aud
the generous manner in which they had been enter-
tain d. Mr Dennis having responded on behalf el St.
Philip’s, si d in reference to p -al-riuginghe was somo-
wcat doubtful as to whether they would bo able to
follow in the footsteps of the return success achieved
by tbe visiting team, for they were heavih handicapped
by being situated in a neighbourhood of private
dwellings, and this caused numerous applications to
have Ibe bells silenced. ■*, e.

IN THE CAPTURED CITY OF SYDNEY.
GENERAL: “ Where are the rest of your troops ? ”
PRISONER: “There’s no more. These are all we could afford after paying the 25s. subsidy to the States.’"
GENERAL: “ What did the States want 25s. for? ”
PRISONER: “So that Mr. Wade could abolish the income-tax.”
GENERAL: “ Where are the people who were relieved of the income-tax? ”
PRISONER : “ They were killed in the bombardment.”

A SEA SERPENT IN THE HUON RIVER. /
“Mr. Robert states that about 4 p./m. on
Tuesday, July 25, he was returning to Garden
Island Creek from Huon Island in a small
punt, and when off the north point of
Charlotte Cove, about a mile below the
Garden Island Cove Creek jetty, he
saw some creature in the water
which was quite unknown to him.
It had, when first seen, elevated
a long neck about 20ft. out of
the water, with a triangular-
shaped flat head bent at
right angles to the
neck.”
No, there is not much gate-money in
the honest admiration of a mere com-
patriot.

THE SYDNEY TOWN HALL MEETING LAST MONDAY.
HIS COLONIAL OATH ; THE PARSONS TRYING TO REVIA T E THE SMOULDERING EMBERS.
Rev. Mervyn Archdall, M.A., was received with tremendous applause as he rose to move the first resolution, which was worded as follows “ That this meeting protests against any alteration
being made in the form of the Coronation Oath and Declaration of the Sovereigns of Great Britain, on the following grounds, viz. : —That by the Act of Settlement it is decreed that the Sovereign of
these realms shall be of the Protestant baith; that the aggressive claims and attitude of the Roman Catholic Church are such that it is necessary that there shall be no relaxations of the safeguards
which ensure the continuance of the Protestant succession; that, as the Roman Catholic doctrine of mental reservation permits oaths to be taken in other than their generally-accepted meaning, it is
incumbent on the Sovereign to make his declaration in terms that are not capable of being taken in any other than their ordinary and obvious meaning, and to declare his adhesion to the Protestant
Faith in terms that cannot be misunderstood.

The Bulletin
Vol. 49—No. 2515.
April 25, 1928.
Shrapnel Green
DO you remember on Shrapnel Green,
On that far-off bitter November day,
When the snow lay thick, and the wind blew keen,
And the blanketed dead in a long row lay,
When your gaze went over the tideless sea
Where rode the monitors grey and grim,
The words you said when you turned to me
With voice grown husky, and eyes grown dim.
You watched for a moment a ’plane’s swift climb,
And you said, as a great gun belched its flame:
“Surely to God there will be a time
When men won’t come at this devilish game!
Have you forgotten the words you spoke
When the dead in their blankets lay very still,
The words you said in a voice that broke,
With a monitor searching for Beachy Bill,
And Imbros rising across the sea,
And a fast ’plane sliding across the sky—
To the left a rattle of musketry,
And we poor fools in a world awry,
Pausing awhile in our bitter task
To wonder vainly what it could mean?
Have you forgotten, old mate, I ask
The prayer you uttered on Shrapnel Green?
Did you catch a gleam from a vanished age ?
Did you hear an echo from other years?
Did you catch a murmur of ancient rage
And see sad eyes that were dim with tears?
Did you see men figHt for an ancient wrong
As men would fight in the years to come?
Did you see the galleys and hear the song
Of victors homing from Ilium?
What had you seen when you turned to me?
Whence came the prayer that I heard you say
When your gaze went over the old, old sea
On that far-off bitter November day?
To Shrapnel Green there has come once more
The quiet dreams that the great guns broke;
Men have returned to the ways of yore.
But one remembers the words you spoke
With a monitor shelling along the right,
And shrapnel bursting above Lone Pine,
And the shell-torn Green ’neath its pall of white,
And the blanketed dead in a long still line.
I know not whither your path has led,
Your name’s forgotten, but this I know.
The world has need of the prayer you said
On Shrapnel Green in the long ago.
Westralia. OSCAR WALTERS.

The Opposition has abandoned the ground of policy and is contenting itself with a campaign of onseruputous calumny and abuse. The reason given for the adoption of this
course is the extraordinary one that the Government has stolen all the Opposition's legislative trump cards. Even if the Government had committed the tlueft of Mr. McGowen's
precious policy, as it is charged with having done, that act from a sincere politician in the Opposition leader’s place might he expected to evoke quite a different kind of feeling. He
Caucus from being carried into effect.-Sydney TELEGRAPH.

WA DE: "My dear sh, clothes were made to be worn, You say they are good clothes, so you should be glad to see me wear them. It
is a compliment to you. It shows that I appreciate your taste. Every man whose goods are stolen should be grateful to the thief."

an extraordinary sermoto^
“SECRETS OF THE BALLROOM.”
WANTON WOMEN RENOUNCED.
MELBOURNE, Sunday,—The Rev. George
Gladstone, incumbent ot Holy Trinity Church,
Nathalia, preached to-night on “Secreta of the
Ballroom,” taking for his text, "They have be-
gun to wax wanton.” The church was crowded,
and the rev. gentleman's remarks werb received
with frequent expressions of dissent, and also
with laUghter J'e had noticed, he said, the most
wanton women in Nathalia were church-
goers, but they did not attend his church, hav-
ing been driven out. The ballroom was a char-
nel house, where those who attended brushed
shoulders with wantons and harlots. A wanton,
he said, was a married woman who had one hus-
band, and wanted two or three more. Tho
women of Goulburn Valley were cursed with tho
spirit Of wantonness, and next time they saw
in the local press the names of married women
attending these white corrobaries they would
know them as wantons —as women who had one
husband a piece, but who wished tor more.

“He believed in the union of Australia and the founding of an Australian nation, and he spoke the mind of a grat many members in thar House. (Opposition
cheers.) If they were to depart from their present Constitution let it be to have a flag of their own under an independent Constitution as the United States of Australia. (Oppsi-
tion cheers.) He held these opinions as a native of the soil and he claimed that they were as well entitled to be considered as those of the Premier, who was not a native of the
soil. The time was not ripe for separation yet, and he would not be one to do anything to bring about a severance at the present time. (Hear, hear.") This country had one of
the grandest futures that any country in the world eon Id possess. That future was to be built up by the creation of a new order of things under the flag of the United States of

THE PARSON OR THE TIGER.
“The Sunday Opening of Sydney Zoo. — lb was reported at the monthly meeting of the East Sydney Ministers’ Association, held yesterday morning in the
Bourke-street Congregational School-hall, that the action of the Government in subsidising the Zoological Gardens for the purpose of admitting the public free
on Sundays had already considerably affected the attendance of children at the Sunday schools in the district. And it was resolved unanimously that the free admis-
sion of children to the Zoo on Sundays, on the plea of educational advantages, is unnecessary, as all children of the public schools are admitted free on certain week-
days; and, further, that it is wrong for Government to vote money to secure for one section of the community privileges of which another section cannot
conscientiously avail itself.”— Daily Paper.

THE DRY DOG, AND OTHER FOLLIES.

Dyspeptic Emesis
A LONG PERIOD OF SUFFERING.
A Permanent Cure in Newtown,
The Case of Mrs. G. WALKER-
(For the “Independent.”)
A subject necessarily inviting to all, and
the discussion of which has of late years
employed many able pens, was recently
touched upon by Mrs. Gertrude Wall er, of
No. 17 George-street, Newtown, when chat-
ting with our special representative.
•‘lt is in reference to the most effective
means of getting rid of one’s j ersonal
enemies that I wish to speak to you,” said
Mrs Walker, “ and I think that I am
entitled to speak on the subject because my
liver was out of order for a long time and
my sufferings were extraordinary. I am
twelve 3 ? ears older sinoe my troubles beg n
with an attack 01 neuralgia, which I
endured for three months without abate-
ment. The teirifle pains lodge !in the back
of my head at first, then they affected my
gums, which became very sore, making it
impossible to properly mas Date my food,
and ‘hen the tortures shot up to my eyes.
Later on there was not a part of my head
which escaped the maddening agonies of
neuralgia, and often I thought they would
drive me out of my mind.”
“ I expect you gob but very little sleep ? ”
enquired the writer.
“Sleep was de»/.ed me altogether,” re-
spond'd Mrs. Walker. “Often I have paced
the floor for hours when everybody else has
been fast asleep, ar;d when morning came I
was not fit for anything. My n rves were
all of a shake, nervousness having such a
hold upon me that I was afraid of my own
shadow, and w en a knock came to the door
it caused me to tremble so violet tly that I
could scarcely move. I was afraid at every
turn, an idea being in my mind continually
that somebody was standing behind me,
though when I looked round there was
_itabody, and I could on'y teproaeh myself
for my folly. Still, I could not help feeling
timid, and to be so every moment of the day
had the effect of making me fretful and
despondent. I lost flesh till I became as
thin as a skeleton, for which I blame my
poor appetite and the trouble I had in keep-
ing my food down. My stomach was in a
dreadfully weak condition, a fact which
accounted for the frequent fits of von iring
I had, for it was all the same in < fleet w hut
kind of food I took—it would not stay
down. Many a time I thought I was going
to be suffocated by the sense of oppression
in my chest, for when it w. s at iis worst I
had to gasp for breath in a most a'arming
way. I could not make out what was
wrong a little distance below my neck.
There seemed to be something pricking me
there—a very tantalising sensation—although
at other times the pain was as gieat as if I
had strained myself. I cani.ot imagine
anything more vile than the taste which was
in my mouth, and to make it mere un-
pleasant still there was a coating on my
tongue which made me feel quite sick. On
arising from bed I was distressed by the aches
running through my legs and across my
loins, for they set at difiance any attempt I
might make to do any light work about the
house, although at the best of tim< s I was
so easily overpowered by exhaustion that I
had to let matters take their own course.”
Did you obtain advice from any
source ? ”
“ I should rather think so. A doctor
from Sydney was doing his best for me, yet
1 cannot say there was anything latisfacio y
resulting from his treatment. lam sure his
medicines did not benefit me, because my
internal troubles multiplied week by week.
If 1 walked a few yaids I was biought to a
standstill by an attack if giddiness, and on
many occasions when I walked a little
distance in the garden a mysterious sensa-
tion come over me which made it appear
that the further I walked the fmthcr the
fence seemed to be away. And then my
heart gave rise to serious reflections The
slight eat excitement or exertion always caused
it to flutter and throb, but even when I was
sitting still it used to suddenly start pal-
pitating with such vengeance that its
beatings could be heard quite distinctly.
The shaip pains which ran through my heart
f'om time to time also lent color to the idea
that it wasdiseased inse me wayor other, and
as the physio I was taking did not alleviate
my sufferings in the least, it appeared
certain that I was going to be an invalid
for life. With my yellow skin and my
features distorted by the physicial agony
and the anxitty of mind I was enduring, I
looked as if my days were almost numbered,
but now, thank Ifeaven, there is a great
difference in my t ppcanim e, and although
I am over thirty years of age, I feel as young
and active as a girl of sixteen.”
“Can you account for such a wonderful
transformation. ”
“ Easily Clements Tonic did it, and only
for an old fiiend who told me about that
medicine I might still be suffering, or per-
haps be dead, as nothing else could cure me.
Several days passed before I felt any better
by taking Clements Tonic, and I was

SATURDAY, AUGUST 1, 1896.
Price, 6d.
G. REID’S PIECE OF COLD IRON.
According to a return presented to N.S.W. Parliament by Premier Reid, certain Government stores which cost £10,132 in N.S.W., cost, in Victoria, £21,069. “That,” said
G. H. Reid, “is a piece of cold iron for Protectionists to chew.” The figures have since been proved to be erroneous in almost every particular, and the official who is alleged to have drawn
them up has been called on for an explanation.
LITTLE BOY AT MANLY: “Here's your bit of cold iron. I've brought it back red-hot for you to chew. Take a bite."

Australia has veen staggered, in moderntion, by the news that its great Cook and Bottlewasher Ministry is preparing a measure by which the Common-
wealth is to take over the State debts. This is a great idea-a most commendable idea-and the matter should have been attended to long ago. If Cook
carries it out on a satisfactory basis, "The Bulletin" will hall him (to his great surprise. and to its great surprise also) as the greatest financier Australia has
produced.-"The Bulletin," 4/9/'13.

Recent London cables :
“SONS OF THE EMPIRE.-PROPOSED TABLET IN
ST. PAUL’S.
“London, Tuesday.— A cartoon showing the Princess Louise’s
design for a bronze memorial is now on exhibition in St. Paul’s
Cathedral. The design shows an angel with outstretched wings lean-
ing tenderly over a figure of the crucified Redeemer. It is intended
for a tablet commemorating the deeds of the colonial sons of the
Empire in the late war.”
“ London, 20th October.—Mr. Cresswell was examined yesterday
before the Rand Native Labor Commission. He stated that the chair-
man of the London directorate of his company had written to him
privately to the effect that Messrs. Wernher, Beit and Co. and other
Rand mining magnates had been consulted on the question of employ-
ing unskilled white labor, and that they were adverse. They feared
that the engaging of a large number of white laborers on the Rand
would ‘ cause the same troubles as had prevailed in Australia,’ and
would enable a combination of labor to dictate the rates of wages,
and to dictate also politically when responsible government came to
be established in the Transvaal.”

posing teams, and after many blows had been
struck the crowd rushed the ground and stopped
play. The WilliamstdWn team left the ground,
and their opponents remaining until time was up,
the umpire gaVe his decision in their fa.vor.

bourne was also a rough and' tumble, and the
spectators witnessed the players, squaring up to
eich other. Sparrow, of the South team, was'
Carried off the ground.

A BALLAD OF HEROES.
[FOR THE BULLETIN.]
The parsons bend and the parsons pray 5
For the boys who’re off to a distant fray;
The hold is packed with the choicest cheer,
The hero’s chest is aburst with beer. f
The girls have laughed and the girls "have cried,
The crowd it crushed till it nearly died,
For the shufflers stay while the heroes roam —
And the Lord will hustle for the folks at home i

The drought is fierce and the drought is fell,
The plains are black as the hobs of hell,
The cattle are a-dyin’ and the sheep are dead;
The folks are famished but the crows are fed;
There’s no fine talk for a fight like this,
No beer at call with a girl to kiss :
It’s a slouch that’ll stand it when the heroes roam ;
O, the Lord will hustle for the folks at home 1
So fling*your flags on the mornin’ breeze—
(This “ Duty first! ” is a poor old wheeze).
There’s drums and fifes and a fine old flare—
(A plague and curse on the old black care !)
A man must go when the bugles cry,
Though the young ones droop and the old ones die ;
It’s a slouch that lingers when the heroes roam ;
O, the Lord will hustle for the folks at home 1

Choeus :
But Dad is a-stickin’ to the plough,

Bor the bbys are far on the blue sea’s foam,
And the Lord will hustle for the folks at home

THE ALTERNATIVE—ARBITRATION OR THE STRIKE.
"We have heard more than once to-day of the great Maritime Strike of 1890, which killed enterprise for a time, which inflicted upon the coal trade a blow
from which it has never recovered, and which was responsible, in a large measure, for the banking crises of a few years afterwards-well, I tell you that that strike
would be only a swaddling infant compared to the gigantic upheaval that would result from a strike to-day. It is either that or the Arbitration Court, and employers
should not forget it."-MR. W. M. HUGHES.

“ Mr. Reid’s speech last night practically indicates his extraordinary
contortionist attitude on the Convention Bill. No great public measure
was ever more effectively damned with faint praise. And yet, after
nearly two hours’ candidly hostile criticism of the measure, he startled
and staggered his audience by declaring his intention to vote for it. Mr.
Reid has been straddling on the Federal rail ever since the Convention
closed. . . '. His acceptance of the Bill as it is framed, even when
given somewhat reluctantly, is embarrassing to his friends and supporters
in,local politics.” —Syd. Daily Telegraph.

this. You arc not my little dog any more ! ”

BASE INGRATITUDE.
If it be true, as alleged, that money is being withdrawn from Australia, it is a matter of great satisfaction. There have been times when this country
required all the money that could be obtained from any source whatever, but that is not the case now. Never before was there such an abundance of capital.
They had much better send their money where it is required.— Palmer’s Sydney Share-Market Circular.
COHEN: “Oh, the injustice of it! Vy, his friends tell him not to borrow any more moneysh from me just pecause he don’t vant it. And
after all the nice interest I’ve let him pay me all these years—Oh, Repecca, the ingratitude of these Christians vill preak my heart.”

MINISTERIAL TRir TO THE
NORTH.
Mr. Reid and Mr. Young began their
northern tour yesterday. On arriving
at Tenterfleld, they were welcomed by the
Mayor and the citizens. The Mayor, Mr. J.
H. Reid, entertained the party at luncheon
at his fine residence overlooking the town.
As he is a total abstainer, no liquor was
given banquet, * ' *»»».*..
On Thursday they will proceed by water tq
Woodburn, the Broadwater sugar mill, and
the mouth of the river, ending up with ban-
quet No. 4 at Ballina, where the harbor
works are to be inspected. On Friday there
will be a visit to the Rous sugar mill, with
banquet No. 6at Lismore f-n Saturday the
party will go to Byron Bay, then take the
tarin to Brunswick and Tho Tweed, where
No. 6 banquet will take place, .'.ft.v tnls
the party are to travel down the river to
catch the train for Brisbane. There are to
be various deputations on the way,-the most
important being a conference with sugar-
growers and others interested in the indus-
try, to be held at Lismore. This deputation
will submit proposals for assistance to tbc
sugargrowers in lieu of the duties ofi
imported sugar.

COLD CHARITY.
In order to mitigate the serious unemployed trouble in Great Britain the Admiralty ordered five new cruisers to be constructed by private shipbuilding firms. The
authorities also invited tenders for 14 large ocean-going destroyers at an earlier period, than they otherwise would have done, in order to give work to the men who were idle.
John Bull gives his famishing unemployed a cup of water, while his protected neighbor helps himself by the bucketful.

THE NEW STATES REPORT.
“The N. S. Wales New States Commission has reported against the creation of new States on the ground mainly that their establishment would add to the cost of government."
PERCIVAL: “I’ve come to ask your permission, sir, to set up a new home wih your daughter.”
DAD: “Young man, if you’ve got any money to spare, give it to me. Don’t waste it in putting up a new roof when you’ve got one over you already.”

Tl\e Finger Post to Health.
This is an Interesting Story
for Liver Sufferers.
The casts of
Mr. G. HEATHCOTE.
(BY A SPECIAL REPORTER.)
Since enlightened humanity requires that
the trials incidental to sickness should be
minimised wherever possible, and since by
kindliness and consideration much can be
done in that direction, a reporter called
upon Mr. George Heathcote, of Surry-
street, Waterloo, who willingly assented
to answer any questions.
“ Were you once a resident of Bunda-
berg, Queensland? ” asked the pressman.
“ Yes,” answered Mr. Heathcote. “ I
was living there when it was necessary to
cross the bridge by boat instead of walking
over it, or, to be more explicit, during the
time of the great flood, and it was during
that exciting and disastrous period that my
blood was so impoverished through exces-
sivi ly hard work for long hours at a stretch
that sores broke out on my hands and arms,
and my legs swelled terribly. Previous to
this I had suffered from fever and ague,
which left me very weak and shaky, and
for some weeks I noticed that my appetite
was falling off ; but I put that down to
fatigue more than anything else, until other
symptoms cropped up to show me it was
not so, but my liver and kidueys which
were responsible.”
“ What reasons were there to enable you
to arrive at that conclusion ? ”
“ Any number of them, one of the most
unmistakable being a nasty pnin which
caught me here (Mr. Heathcote indicated
the part affected by placing his hand on the
small of his back'. My back ached so in-
tensely that my wife made flannel belts for
me to wear, thinking that they would afford
me some relief. If I was doing anything
whi' h caused me to bend down, the pain on
straightening myself was something terrible,
while walking also provoked great distress
and inconvenience. Other proof that my
kidneys were in a bad way was also in
evidence, and as for the rest of my ail-
ments —well, I hardly know where to begin
first. ”
“ 1YU me a few of the mort important —
ihose that are uppermost'in your mind ? ”
“ Oh ! I have not forgotten any of them,”
was the quick response, “especially the
heavy feelings in my chest, which made me
short-winded. After eating, a weighty sen-
sation appeared in that quarter, and before
I knew where I was my stomach began
swelling out with wind, which made me
very uncomforta 1 le. always, and at times
gave rise to sharp, cutting pains. The
sour gases gradually worked their way up,
and caused me to belch, after which, and
until 1 took a little more food, I felt
slightly easier, but the same unpleasantness
followed each meal, however trifling. When
making my morning preparations for work
I used to feel as if I would'tike to go back
to bed again, as I was entirely devoid of
energy, and bed no desire to attempt any-
thing. This languidness was due, no doubt,
to the restlessness every night. I could go
to bed feeling so drowsy that my eyes
seemed swollen for the want of rest, yet I
found myself awake the greater part of the
night, and when I got up my limbs were
all aches. Nearly every day I was dis-
tracted with intense headaches- which ap-
peared to bring a mist befrire lay eyes, as
if my sight was failing me, and without any
warning my head became so giddy that I
had to take a rest till the sen-ation passed
away. Every month I was getting weaker
and more wretched, being continually be-
set with pains under my shoulder-blades,
which travelled right through to the heart,
and caused me considerable anxiety. The
white coating on my tongue explained the
unhealthy condit ; on of my stomach, too,
and what I wanted was a real good medicine
to clear away all disorders and impurities;
but in those days I did not know as much
as I do now, or I would have been out of
my troubles very quickly. I went from
bad to worse, and had arrived at that
melancholy and desperate stage when the
least an>l most simple thing excites a feeling
of irritation, and I am sure yon will admit
that such a life of misery is not worth eu-
(luring. Had I gone on a little longer in
that sorry plight I question whether I
would have been as sound a man as I am
to-day, for I was fairly in the grip of my
complaint, when, owing to the recollection
of some conversations between a few of my
friends, 1 hit upon the idea of taking some
Clements Toir’c. I took immediate action,
as I firmly bel’eved that further delay
would have brought irretrievable disaster
to my.constitution.”
“ Your good fortune came at a very ac-
ceptable time, I should imagine?”
“ Yes ; and a very critical time, too, and
I regretted that I had not bought a few
bottles of Clements Tonic at the outset;
but we all have to buy our experience, you
know, although I intend doing all I can to
help ot her sufferers by letting them know
what Clements Tonic can do. Personally,
I can truthfully say that it generally re-
vived me from my lethargic state when I
had drank but a small quantity, and I found
myself rapidly improving. Clements Tonic
had a magical effect on my kidneys and
greatly reHe- ed the pains about my back
and shoulders. This relief, collided wi h
the abatement of my headaches, had tho
effect of mating me feel more restful at
nights, and the sound sleep 1 got through
using Clements Tonic did me an immense
amo int of good. My slumber was not in-
terfered with by dreams, and when I awo e
a* the usual time for getting up I arose with
alacrity and hastened to my morning meal,
after which I was ready for work. It was
a marvellous change to be full of energy
and cheerfulness again, but the invigorating
properties of Clements Tonic were so re-
markable that I could not have restrained
my feelings of joy had I wanted to. Wind
never formed in my stomach after Clements
Tonic got to work, neither did my chest
trouble me, while in the matter of palpita-
tion tho same medicine was equal to the
prevailing reqniremeti's. There is no
denying the fact that Clements io.uc
was wonderfully effective as a blood
purifier, for the sores were gradiiai;y
effaced from my hands and arms, and the
cause of my legs swelling—whatever that
cause might have been was entirely re-
moved. My illness had considerably
affected my nerves, which became shaky
whenever 1 was disturbed, but to my heart-
felt thankfulness I must say that Clements
Tonic was as effective on my nervous
system as it was on my other deranged
organs.” _
“ VVliat was your appetite like then .
“As it was soon after commencing or.
Clements Tonic—very good, indeed, and it
has remained so ever since. But the
strengthening qualities of my newly-found
medicine surprised me, fur altli 'Ugh my
work was very heavy I always g<>t through
it without feeling any ill effects from the
time Clements I onic cured mo, aiul I have
not once lmd the faintest return of any of
my old symptoms, in acknowledgment of
which I give you permission to publish my
story as it pleases you.”

A RATHER SUDDEN HALT.

that one miserable little rat can hold an army in check ! Here’s a tip for De Wet.

BRITAIN’S FREE BREAKFAST TABLE.
Lord Rosebery says that Britain will never tolerate a tax on food; the “free breakfast table ” must be held inviolate.
The British Amalgamated Society of Carpenters and Joiners (which makes the table to put the free breakfast on) reports for January this year
that in 495 towns or cities of the United Kingdom trade is “bad” (through so few people being able to afford the price of the table); in 213 it
is “ moderate; ” and it isn’t “ good ” in one single place. Wages for skilled workmen range as low as fivepence and one-eighth of a penny per hour.
Apparently the imported British Freetrade breakfast is eaten on the floor these days.

JACK WANT TAKES HIS PLEASURES SADLY.
“Mr. Want at Adelaide.-Contrary to his original intention, Mr. J. H. Want Q.C., Will not proceed to Albany as a passenger by the P. and O. liner Himalaya, which arrived
at Largs Bay early on Thursday morning. 'I will stop in Adelaide as long as I can, 'he remarked to a reporter of the Adelaide ADVERTISER on board the vessel. 'I don't know how
soon I may have to get back,' he stated, as he scanned that morning's newspaper and read the telegram concerning the political situation in New South Walles."-DAILY PAPER.
King Cabbage-Tree will soon have to do his fishing at Circular Quay, as above.

.leisured run of tho correspondence is stringing the
negotiations out for an unconscionable time. Steps
are now being taken by the Ministry to ascertain
wbat the Secretary of State for the Colonies in-
tends to do in the matter.

men. Last week two policemen, by concealing

QUEEN VICTORIA'S CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTION—AGAIN.
Queen Victoria has sent to Queensland her “sympathy” (unaccompanied by a cheque) and here you have a flooded-out family making use of it. The father is seen in
the foreground keeping himself and children dry with it, while in the middle distance may be seen the mother cooking some of it for their frugal meal, crooning in an
undertone “God save the Queen!”

AN ANCIENT PARABLE (EVERY PAR-
ABLE OUGHT TO BE ANCIENT) FOR
JAWBONE NEILD. CONROY AND CO.
Once upon a time a Bulldog and a very elo-
quent Cockatoo inhabited the same yard.
Now, the' Bulldog slept pretty constantly, and
the Cockatoo, to take a rise out of him, used to
hop down and whisper in his ear, “ Sool ’em,
Bully ' ” Whereupon Bully would arise and bark
furiously and strain on his chain, only to find
that there was nothing to sool
Bully resolved to see who was fooling him.
So he slept one "day with one eye open. When
the Cockatoo next tried to pull his leg, he grabbed
a big mouthful of feathers from that bird’s tail.

Melbourne, Sunday.—At a dinner to
Colonel Williams, In Ballarat, the \
Minister for Defence expressed the ,V
opinion that Australian citizen soldiers 3
would never learn thoroughly what dis- 1
clpllne was until they had taken part /
in war. The great difficulty in military
. matters was discipline,
x
A peculiar find of gold has, It Is said, been made by a
resident of* Linton. A goose was killed, and on being
opened, rough specks of gold were found, the lot being
about three-quarters of a penny-
weight, valued at 38.. Evidently
the gold had been picked up
whilst the goose was feeding on
the roads. '
Our artist here depicts a veteran who
has been thoroughly “disciplined.”
Practical discipline is all right, but
there’s such a thing as over-doing it.
A well known firm of London pub-
lishers has brought out a series of pic-
tures to “Advertise Australia,” one of
which shows a squad of convicts drawn
up on the sloping shores of Sydney
Cove, and being addressed by an official
regarding their future career. The
series has been withdrawn.
Intending Emigrant: “Look ’ere,Nance,
If they makes long speeches to their
immygrants when the’ arrives let’s
go som’eres else.”
It Is safe to predict that the geese of Linton are going to have a
pretty warm time of it in the future.

An interesting opinion on the point
was given by a legal authority, who
maintains that an action for trespass
would He against the user of an aero-
plane who passed or paused at a low
elevation over another man’s land. It
is, he points out, a well-known princi-
ple of law that a freeholder owns the
■oil and all beneath it and ail above it.

afternoon.—A second
interim report has
been issued by the
Royal Commission on
Tuberculosis, which
declares that, as a
result of elaborate
experiments, cow’s
milk, containing
bovine tubercle
bacilli, has
been found
to be clearly
the cause of
fatal tuber*
culosis in
man.
This will cause the Fatman
to adopt new styles of
landscape gardening.
Hence the man at the pump winks audibly.

“THE FIVE NATIONS.”
LONDON, Wednesday.—The TIMES states this morning that the Dominions are being driven at a dozen points into the practical world of politics on their own account, and
are acquiring interests sometimes conflicting with Britain’s. Unless there is a mutual understanding, the five nations will find it impossible to continue the system whereby British
foreign policy remains a sealed book to all but one partner. “It is necessary,” the paper adds, “that our policy be strengthened by becoming Imperial and securing the
conscious and continuous support of the Governments overseas.”

“At a special Cabinet meeting consideration was given to the cases of Selina Sangal and August Tisler, sentenced to death last month for the Dandenong murder. It was decided that
the law should be allowed to take its course in both cases, and Tisler was hanged on Monday. The date of the execution could, of course, not be definitely fixed in the case of Mrs. Sangal,
who has not yet been told that the Executive has confirmed her sentence, and it is unlikely that the news will be broken to her until after her accouchement. - ’—IVews Ttem.

THE DOG AND THE BIT OF MEAT: A FABLE.
There was once a Small Boy who offered a Large Dog a Bit of Meat. It wasn’t his Dog Either. There was a String attached to the Meat and
when the Dog reached for the Meat the Small Boy snatched it Away and Laughed. He did this to show his Importance and to assert his State
Frights, for the Small Boy didn’t require the Meat and he had no Business with the Large Dog. in the end the Large Dog chased the Small Boy
over the Horizon, and he is Running Yet.

LONDON, Saturday. Among the dis-
tinguished scientists attending the Zoological
Conference at Cambridge is, Professor
Haeckel, whose researches with regard to
natural development and evolution have
been of great value
At the sitting of the conference yesterday,
Professor Haeckel referred to the import-
ance attaching to the discoveries of fossils
in lava during recent years, and said that
it was no longer a hypothesis that man
belonged to the primal order of lemur.
Conclusive proof--’had been afforded that
'monkeys and men were descended- from a
common stem.

IN THE PUBLIC EYE.
The constant sneer or curse or lamentatlon of the two Sydney Foreign-trade morning papers about "Victorian Manufactures,” while N.S.W.
manufactures are never even mentioned by them, is at last leading the outside public to believe that the Ma State has no factories of its own.

consequence the outside person begins to see with his mind’s eye things similar to the above.

RELIGIOUS INSTRUCTION.
Visiting Parson (to country public
. , school) : “Now, can any little
boy repeat the first Commandment ? ’• *
Chorus: “Bill, d your eyes, git up and bring in the cows! ”

A GENUINE EXERCISE IN
COMPOSITION, BY A BOY
13 YEARS OLD.
“Sir, —You ask me how
1 spent King’s Birthday.
Well, my father called me
to get the cows at 4 a.m.
“Then 1 pumped water for the cows,
and gave them some feed, while my
brother got the horses ready to deliver
the milk in round the
town.
“We drove in and
delivered the milk, and
got back at half-past 7.
I cut the feed for the
cows,
“ an< J pumped some more water.
Then had breakfast.
“ I got up and drove them in.
I milked nine.
“After breakfast I turned the separ-
ator, and then fed the pigs. We
pumped more water for the cows, and
gave them more feed.
•* After dinner we cut some
lucerne got the cows in
to milk.” Then, having repeated the]
morning’s programme—with more pump*
ing, of course—the essay winds up
with: “Then I had tea, and went to
bed”—having first, let us hope, sang “God Save the King.”
THE DEVIL—IS HE A COW?

HIS CHRISTMAS BLOW-OUT!

Before Taking Clements Tonic,
MISERY & HELPLESSNESS.
After Taking Clements Tonic,
CHEERFULNESS & ACTIVITY.
A Very Convincing Narrative.
The Case of Mr. P. B. HUNT,
(BY A SYDNEY REPORTER.)
The ready compliance of Mr. Percy
Bordon Hunt, of No. 8 The Terrace,
Bourke-street, Redfern, with the request
of a special interview, illustrates a
series of difficulties and complica-
tions from which there was no immediate
prospect of escape. After mentioning that
he was a native of London and a resident of
these colonies for the last ten years, Mr.
Hunt went on to say :
“ It was when I came out to this country
that I had a very bitter experience with bad
health, and I hope I shall never have to go
through anything like it again, as once in a
life-time is quite enough. I had previously
suffering from a complaint called locemotor
ataxia, and I had never felt really well since.
The change in climate evidently did not
suit me, for my head started to ache most
unmercifully, making me feel quite unfit to
take part in anj thing- I was so drowsy
and low-spirited, too, no pleasant thoughts
ever coming to give me a moment’s happi-
ness, and I did not seem to care what
happened.”
“ Did you receive any medical attention?”
asked the writer.
“Yes. I had been to several hospitals,
where the doctors prescribed physic for me,
but it could not have been suitable for my
complaints, as it took no effect upon me.
Their medicines were so useless that I might
as well have thrown them down the drain.
The doctors said it was next to impossible
to properly recover from 'the complaint
which had made a wreck of me, and this was
and awful reflection for one who had always
been so hale and hearty before, and naturally
making me more sad and hopeless than ever ;
but I thought I would try some other
medicine before giving up all hope, and
when I had done so my condition was just
as bad as ever. I could not get my breath
freely owing to the heavy sensation in my
chest, and 1 could not sleep at all well. If
I did doze off I was made restless by
dreams that were most repulsive, and, once
more finding myself awake, I dreaded the
thought of falling asleep again because the
dreams were so unpleasant. That was
through being sc nervous, I suppose, for I
trembled at the slighest noise and was
excited at every turn. My mouth had a
nauseating taste which I imagined came
from the white coating on my toi gue. and
there was such a strange feeling about my
eyes—a heavy sensation as if they had
swollen during the night. When in Louden
I was secretary to one of the most eminent
Congregational ministeisin the city, and con-
sequently had a great amount of brain work
to do, so that when I came here and felt so
brain-weary and fagged out I felt my position
all the more keen y. There was no life in
me, and I gave myself up as helpless to
throw oft the utter deadness of vitality
under which I was existing. Simply through
excessive weakness my limbs were racked
with aches. It was just the same in the
morning after lying down all night, for my
legs were as tired as if I had been climbing
steep hills instead of trying to rest myrslf,
and the mere thought of going to work made
me shudder in despair. Ihere was something
radically wrong with my loins, too, as tho
painful aches across them caused me no end
of inconvenience, and more so when I had
to walk to any place. But so far as that
goes there was nothing that I could find any
pleasure in doing, as my loss of energy was
so great that it was almost a trouble to dress
myself, For a man whose temperament is
naturally active and energetic it was a
terrible hardship to be in such a weak and
powerless condition, but the most melancholy
phase of the situation was that I could get
no medicine to help me out of my difficulties.
| It seemed a forlorn hope to think of recover*
ing my health again, but was there anything
I had not given a trial to ? I asked myself. A
little reflection told me that Clements Tonid
had escaped my notice up till now, and ad
my deplorable state of feebleness required
immediate attention I said I would give il
a trial.”
“ Were you pleased that you did so.”
“My word I was, for Clements Tome
acted on my system as no other medicind
had done. Do you know that I had no real
appetite from the time I was taken ill until
I took Clements Tonic, which made me so
hungry that I was always wanting food. ]
was overjoyed at this success, especially as
my pains were diminishing with each bottle
of Clements Tonic,which made my digestive
apparatus able and willing to assimilate my
food and fill my veins with pure, rich 1 lood,
and with my heart strong and vigorous to
pump that blood to every part of my body.
As time went on it became apparent that I
was on the road to recovery, as my head-
aches and giddiness were gone and my sigh!
was good. I breathed freely owing to chest
pains being relieved, while the flatulence
which had affected my stomach did nol
trouble me after using a few bottles ol
Clements Tonic. Would it be possible for
me to speak too well of a medicine which
did so much for me when all others failed!
My opinion is that I will never be able to
liquidate my debt to Clements Tonic for its
miraculous influence over me, for it actually
raised me from misery and helplessness to a
life of cheerfulness and activity. This was
done by degrees, of course, for I got
stronger because I was getting plenty of
rest, my sleep being sound and dreamless,
and the morning life found me equipped for
the duties of life as I had not been for many
a day. I was no longer sickened by a bitter
taste and a dry tongue when I woke up,
neither was I troubled with that weariness
of limb which had made all my movements
so irksome. I had reason to look at life in
an entirely different aspect then, thank Cod,
as tho pain-tilling properties of Clements
Tonic gave such prompt relief tliut I was
soon free from all my torments, and as a
remedy for invigorating the nervous system
I am sui e that medicine is the best in the
world. My nerves were so ready and keen
that my daily work became a pleasure, and
a capacity for physical and mental exc rtiou
proportionally increased. I did not re-
linquish the use of Clements Tonic until my
health was as sound as it had ever been,
being an entirely new man, and as I have
since enjoyed immunity from the ailments
waich nothing but Clements Tonic could
cure it is only fair to my fellow colonists
that I should tell them by what means I
was released from wretchedness.”
“It will be necessary to print your
statements, then.”
“ Of course it will; and you may publkflt
them in any way you like.”
STATUTORY DECLARATION.
I, Perct Bordon Bust, of 8 The Terrace, Bourke-
street, lledfern, in the Slate of New South Wales,
Commonwealth of Australia, do solemnly and sin-
cerely declare that I have catefully read the
annexed document, consisting of four folios,
and consecutively numbered from one to four,
and that it contains and is a true ind faithful
account of my illness and cure by Clements Tonic,
and also contains my full perndssion to publish
in any way my statements—which I give volun-
tarily without receiving any payment; and I make
this solemn d claration conscientiously believing
the same to be true, and by virtue of the provisions
of The Oaths Act. 1900.
Subscribed and declared at Redfern, this twenty*
second d«y of April, one thousand nine hundred and
two. before me. PATRICK STANLEY. J.P.

Nervous Prostration
A Dreadful Period of Suffering,
“Clements Tonic Saved Me,”
Tho Case o! Itys. E. WEEDEN.
(BY A SPECIAL REPORTER.)
As great interest was manifested in all
circles respecting the following subject, a
representative waited on Mrs. Elizabeth
Weeden, of No. 67 Cleveland-street, Rcd-
fern, who is well known in the locality in
which she lives.
“ I am pleased that you have called,”
said Mrs. Weeden, “ as it gives me an op-
portunity to let the public know what was
my real position at the time you refer to,
and also to remove any misapprehensions
which might exist in the minds of some of
my neighbours. It appears that the
general assumpti n was that I had profited
in health by following a certain course of
treatment recommended by my doctor. No-
thing of the sort was the case, for after
carrying out his instructions for a long time
my prospects were no brighter, so I gave
him up and tried to get relief through the
aid of several medicines which I had seen
advertised in the papers. They were no
less effective, and as they all failed to reach
the base of my afflictions I thought I wa’s
never going to have my health back again.”
“ What was the nature of your com-
plaint t ” enquired the reporter.
“ The doctor said it was nervous prostra-
tion from which I was suffering, and I think
he was right, for I used to tremble as if an
electric battery was at work all through my
body, while the fearsome state of my mind
was most distressing, as I was always
fancying that some terrible trouble was
hanging over me. If the children were not
home from school to time I worried myself
with the belief that something had happened
to them, and such anxiety seemed to make
me very irritable and short-tempered. I
was alwa\s tired and extremely drowsy,
ft cling at 9 o’clock in the morning as if I
could go to bed and sleep all day, such a
th ng as a desire to get my work done sel-
dom entering my head. Careless and in-
different to everything around me, my life
was one oontinual misery. There was a
depressing pain in my head as if a bai d had
been drawn tightly over my before
which little dark specks frequently floated,
and sometimes I could scarcely see for a
haziness which appeared in front of me. I
used to imagine I had a touch of ear-ache,
owing to a peculiar sensation like the sound
of a bell ring ng in my ears, while the
shocking headaches I had to endure 1 shall
never forget. You have no idea how
wretched I felt when I had eaten a few
mouthfuls of food. My stomach became
filled with wind, from which I suffered great
pain until sour belchings came on, when I
feijt a little easier ; but, in the meant me,
my chest was proving very troublesome,
with a feeling as if a load of some kin 1
was going to smother mo. Then I com-
menced to feel s'ck, and before long my
food was retched up again. I had the most
| awful pains in my side and shoulders; but
the manner in which my heart palp tated
caused me many a fright. If I walke i a few
yards my heart fluttered dreadfully, so you
may depend I exerted myself as little as
possible, more especially as I felt faint and
giddy when I moved about. After the least
effort to do a little work I used to collapse,
my feebleness being so marked that if I
tried to sweep a room my strength failed so
I completely that I ft It powerless, even to
I the tips of my fingers.”
’ “ You spoke about feeling so drowsy all
day. How did you pass your nichts?”
“ Well, I was in such a sluggish condition
that I could always sleep, but the strange
part about it was that I never felt rested or
refreshed. This was due, no doubt, to the
fact that I had horrible dreams and night-
mares, which made me scream out whilst
asleep. The children have often come to
me in the middle of the night to wake me
up ao that my screaming would cease, and
how terrified I w*s when awakened ! My
month was in a nasty state, too, as if I had
been tasting copper, my tongue also being
covered with fur. I thought my skin would
never get white again, it was that yellow,
and I was about as thin as I could pos-
sibly be. Nobody but those who have had
a similar experience to mine can form the
slightest conception of what mental torture
is involved when pain is endured and all hope
is lost. There was no pleasure in being
alive, but still I clung to what little life was
left, and now you see a different woman al-
together. lam quite well again.”
“ You are very fortunate. But what
made you so ? ”
“ It was a medicine called Clements Tonio
which helped me out of my difficulties, and
but for that remedy I do not know what I
would have done. As the doctor’s and
other medic nes could do me no good it is
only right to say that Clements Tonic saved
me, and I shall always deem it my duty to
make this fact clear to other people. Yes,
it was when I had taken nearly a bottle of
Clements Tonic that I felt warmed and
strengthened, with a good healthy glow
running right through my body, and my
spirits brighter than they had been ever
since my illness began. Getting some more
Clements Tonic, that miserable drowsiness
commenced to leave me, and as I was al-
ready taking a little food I began to pick
up strength. I thought this was splendid
progress, and I was highly elated with
the great success which attended my use
of Clements Tonic—a fact that was borne
out by the abatement of my tortures. My
headaches became so insignificant that I
hardly noticed them ; then they died out
altogether, and I can say the same about
the pains in my side and shoulders. I
was so thankful to be thus relieved, and
still more encouragement to per severe with
Clements Tonic came when flatulence was
remedied and ’ the heaviness was lifted
from my chest. The anxiety which my
heart had caused by palpitating at every
turn was readily set aside by Clements
Tonic, which seemed to find its way to
every nook and corner of my internal
organs and root out every particle of
disease which had been left untouched by
previous medicines. '1 he sleep which then
came was calm and refreshing, and when
I got up it was with a clean mouth and
a good appetite for my morning meal,
and also with a feeling of energy which
ma ’e it a pleasure to have some work
to do. All this time my nervousness was
becoming less apparent in every way. I
could soon tolerate any noise without
trembling, and my mind was free from all
fe >rs. I recognised how different my life
was, and my grateful thoughts were all
centred on Clements Tonic, which I c n-
t nue 1 taking for another week or so, when
I found m self as well i s ever, with my
complexion clear and my weight regained.”
“With y< ur permission I’ll reproduce
this narrative.”
“ You can publish it in any way you like,
as I’ve only spoken the truth."

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1908.
Prioe 6d.
Extracts from report of a women's political
meeting (Sydney)
The Chairman : I think the discussion might be
allowed to go on uninterruptedly.
Mrs. Hamilton Grey : You Parliamentary
humbugs !
The Chairman : Order, order.
Mrs. Hamilton Grey (excitedly) : You and your
policemen.
Mr. Levy : Mr. Chairman, she’s got no right to
interrupt the meeting like this.
Mrs. Hamilton Grey : Oh, I’ll go. I don’t
want to stay here.
The Chairman : I must protect these speakers.
Mrs. Hamilton Grey (excitedly): You miserable
coward to go and talk about me as you did. (Dis-
order.)
Mrs. Hamilton Grey then got up, and with a
parting shot at the chairman, left the hall. Mr.
Levy was being asked by the chairman and others
to continue his remarks, when a second lady got
up and attacked the chairman.
Several gentlemen rose, and attempted to calm
the lady, and others spoke about “ women’s rights
with a vengeance,” but the lady continued to talk
excitedly at the chairman for some seconds, and
then left the room. A third lady now rose and
went out, and, quietness being restored, Mr. Lew
proceeded with his address. —Daily paper.
THE NEW WOMAN: WANTED, THE NEW POLICEMAN.

SONG.
[FOR THE BULLETIN.]
ON a tree by a river a little bird sat,
Singing, “ Fish ! Stinking Fish ! Stinking Fish ! ”
And I asked, “ Oh ! you naughty bird, what are you at
With your “Fish! Stinking Fish! Stinking Fish?”
Then he said it again, and I thought it absurd,
For he was the Australian Commissioner Bird,
And, of course, London laughed ev’ry time that it heard
His loud “Fish! Stinking Fish! Stinking Fish!”
“ Tell me, bird,” I implored, “why that phrase you repeat?
What is ‘ Fish ! Stinking Fish ! Stinking Fish ? ’
Surely that isn’t what you’re accustomed to eat
in your dear little salary dish !
1 refuse to believe that your owner can be
Such a beast as to give you such things for your tea! ”
But he opened his beak, and he hollered at me:
“ I say * Fish ! Stinking Fish ! Stinking Fish ! ’ ”
N.S.W.
Then I said: “Little Bird, that’s a horrid remark,
That bad ‘ Fish ! Stinking Fish ! Stinking Fish ! ’
Who on earth taught you that as you perched in the dark,
Saying, ‘ Fish ! Stinking Fish ! Stinking Fish ! ’ ?
It is very unpleasant. Your own common°sense
Should have told you it’s Lkely to give much offence.”
But he fluttered and flapped with an effort Immense,
And yelled, “ Fish ! Stinking Fish ! Stinking Fish ! ”
“Little Bird,” I remarked, “ere I finally trek,
Take my word that your ‘Fish! Stinking Fish!’
Will yet make us wring your ridiculous neck!
Don’t you ‘Fish ! Stinking Fish ! Stinking Fish! ’ ”
But the cry was embedded too deep in his brain,
And he knew nothing else. That was perfectly plain,
For he made no reply save to do it again.
Just said : “ Fish ! Stinking Fish ! Stinking Fish! ”
KODAK.
THE WRONG BIRD.
Mr. Sparrow, of London, said at the Chamber of Commerce conference that the Canadian representative in London called out all the time “Canada! Canada!
Canada . Australia required a High Commissioner who would incessantly call out “Australia! Australia! Australia! ”
But, unluckily, if John Forrest or Geo. Reid gets the job the cry is more likely to be something as above.

AFTER YOU!
The Washington correspondent of the New York Times reports that Mr. Roosevelt (Assistant Secretary for the Navy) in a speech said: “The limitation
of armaments will be the thought uppermost at the coming Limitation of Armament Conference, but we must never, under any circumstances, put our country
in a position where it would be unable to defend itself against anything and everything arising. Pacifists and muddle-headed idiots will shout for the United
States to set an example, but we must never disarm, and then wait for other armed nations to act.”

HELL'S MENU
The Devil sat and stroked his tail,
And listened to tho howl and wail.
“ By Eden's Snake,” he said at last,
** Hell’s business is growing fast.
We haven’t got a grid to spare,
Although on some I’ve packed a pair.
Nine months ago things were so slow
I nearly let the license go;
But now, the way trade’s pouring in—
Great Sulphur I What an awful din I ”
Just then the chef dashed through the
door 1
And cast himself upon the floor:
44 Great Lord of Flame and Sheol’s Hob,
1 must resign—l chuck the job.
You hear those cursing souls without?
Just mark their furious yell and shout.
They’re there in tens of thousands—
more!
Each day arrives a thousand score!
And, though I’ve tried by day and night
To satisfy their appetite
With roast and grill and boiled and—
well,
Most everything we’ve got in Hell,
They growl like dogs, dread lord, and so
Give me my wage and let me go.
No cook could stand the strain for long,
However healthy he and strong,
When endless lines of waiters crowd,
And clamor ceaselessly and loud.
Three times a day but this I hear:
** Hi! Sausage one and lager beer ! ”

THE GRADUAL DEVELOPMENT OF BULL.
J. Bull has annexed another 15,000 square miles filled with niggers.
(1) There was a white Bull once. (2) Then he became light brown, and bought a turban. (3) He grew still more brown, and
acquired a big sash and a curved sword. (4) His brownness increased, and he acquired petticoats and funny shoes. (5) Gradually he
became so brown that he was practically black, and he undressed himself again and wore a loin=cloth. (6) And in the end he will
annex so many niggers that he will be quite black, and the last scene will be an aboriginal Bull roasting his ’possum over a small fire.

THE STRENGTH OF IT.
“‘lt is a crowning feat,’ says Sir Ernest Budge, the keeper of the Egyptian and A ssyrian antiquities at the British Museum, apropos the discovery by the Earl of Carnarvon
last week of Tutankhamen’s tomb. Tutankhamen’s predecessor, Amenhotep the Fourth, revived the old sun worship. He shut himself up and isolated the city, where he burnt
incense and offered sacrifices, while the empire went to ruin. There is scarcely a more pathetic picture in history than this religious fanatic, singing hymns to the god
whom the people .refused to worship.”— SUN cable.
TOURIST: “But why did he make a god of such an abominable object?”
GUIDE: “The people of his day believed that the god gave him the lyre, and that accounted for his devotion.”
