second Junior football match, Homebush v. Orient-
al. From tl)p start Oriental made the game very,
“willing," and the referee, Mr. H. Hazel, with a
commendable determination to enforce tha rules
regarding rough play, ordered two of the visiting
team off the field. This 1 action, coupled with the
subsequent defeat of the Oriental team by 12
po.nts to nil, so enraged the players_and their
supporters that they proceeded to “deal it ouf’
to the referee at the conclusion of the maicai,
kicking and striking him in the most brutal
nsr, and showering upon him mud and other misA
sues. In self-defence Mr. Hazel was compelled'
to draw a revolver, with which he had coma
armed.

(FOR THE BULLETIN.)
Brumbietown was purely a pastoral town-
ship. All its interest centred in stock and
country. If you were in no way connected with
either you had to be contented with a back seat.
Ihe pert commercial-travellers grew subdued and
retiring when business brought them to Brumbie-
town, and even racing-men were only tolerated on
account of their connection with horseflesh. In
the two leading hotels, resident squatters and
station-managers ruled the roast, whilst their
myrmidons aped them in their absence. In the
two inferior pubs, the shearer, the stockman and
the boundary-rider were supreme, and their yarns
were listened to with the respect due to talent. It
need scarcely be said that Brumbietown possessed
all the usual and natural appendages of a bush
town. I here was, of course, the doctor, who was
such a. clever man when he wasn’t drunk. There were
at least three storekeepers, who combined to live
and let live by keeping prices up ; and there was a
lawyer who was as gifted as the doctor—“ only
for the drink. ” Add to these the usual Govern-
Bient officials, saddler, blacksmith, carriers’ wives,
&c., and you have the population There was no
police-magistrate and no newspaper-man, and,
strange to say, both these long-felt wants were
supplied at the beginning of our story; in fact
but for the combined advent of the two there
would be no story to tell.
* # *
At about the same time that the Govern-
ment came to the conclusion that two Justices
of the -Peace were insufficient for the wants
of the growing population about Brumbietown, an
aspiring compositor who had made a small
rise discovered that a certain fortune lay in
the future support to be accorded to the Brcm-
bietown Star and Wattleshire Advertiser.
Lobbs coach then, on a certain day, dumped
down at Brumbietown the P.M., a hot-tem-
pered old fossil named Lisle, who was always
kept in hand for outside places where he
could do very little harm, and the spirit of the
x ress, in the person of Mr. J, Forman.
Lisle was, and always had been, one of those
uo-account men who pass the whole of their exist-
ence in more or less temporary Government bil-
lets—inevitably “ putting their feet into it ” when
possible ; kept in small positions by some un-
fathomable influence, and, of course, rumoured to
be of good family. Unfortunately, for him his
unknown influence was only good with one party,
and when their opponents were in power he felt
the bitter blast of obscurity. At present his
friends were up in the saddle, and Brumbietown
being in want of aP.M., he had been sent there
to get rid of him. Forman was a steady fellow,
with good business instincts and a knowledge of
ms trade ; he had some misgivings about his
literary ability, but trusted to common-sense and
good luck to pull through.
Whether the advent of that mighty lever, the
Press, was the baneful cause of it or not, from the
date of the first issue of the Star, there were two
hostile camps in the forraerly-.united little com-
munity. Lisle had snubbed “ the infernal news-
paper-man” on his way up, so they were not
cousins. ’ The lawyer really did know some
law when he was sober, while the P.M. didn’t
know a scrap either drunk or sober, so those two
fell out. IS aturally, sides were at once taken, and
before the third number of the Stab had well seen
the light, open war was declared. Whilst this
was the unsatisfactory state of things in the town,
the surrounding country was agitated by the news
that a feud of great bitterness had broken out
between two of the principal stations, so that the
demon of discord had apparently taken possession
of the whole district.
At this time there appeared in the town a
dilapidated traveller, in the state popularly known
as stone-broke. Amongst many other shifts and
dodges he could “pick up stamps’’and write a
little, and to his own intense astonishment found
himself at once installed not on the staff—but as
the staff of the Brumbietown Star, Celebrating
his instalment by one wild, joyous burst of revelry
by night and day, he then buckled to, and under
the watchful eye of Forman promised to develope
into a perfect treasure. His name was Robinson,
he was a young man, and had evidently been well
educated. Into the police-magistrate feud he
ffung himself with an ardour that made Forman
tremble, but, assisted by the lawyer, who for a time
kept preternaturally sober, they safely weathered
the libel law, and made Lisle and the opposition
pastoralist faction gnash their teeth with rage.
Ihe most cherished traditions of Brumbietown
were set at naught. The “ pestilent rag ” agitated
for more commonage to be declared, then for more
areas to be thrown open for selection. It caused
a rush of selectors by its articles on the suitability
of the surrounding land for dairy-farms ; and the
staff sent long letters to the metropolitan papers,
which, although cut down to a “stick,” were
headed‘‘Brumbietown,”and served to advertise
the district as suitable for selection.
It was evident that this sort of thing would have
to be put a stop to or the town and the surround-
ing country would go to the devil. It was pro-
posed to establish an opposition paper, but as that
would evidently prove a loss, the idea was dis-
missed. Then, aided and abetted by the P.M.,
whose blunders and favouritism had been ruth-
lessly exposed in the Star, the leader of the
squatting party, who had suffered severely from
the selecting rush, laid a deep scheme to annihilate
‘the staff.” Robinson, who, under the excitement
of battle, and out of gratitude to his new friend
Forman, had kept wonderfully straight, was fond
of a good horse. He had made friends with the
manager of a station about ten miles from the
town, who was one of the parties to the feud
before spoken of, and from Saturday to Mon-
day he usually stayed with the manager.
One Monday forenoon the staff was touch-
ing up a leader which he had thought
out on his way back in the early morning,
and which he calculated would make the other
side go and hang themselves with their own belts,
when he was astonished by the entry of the local
policeman who arrested him on a charge of horse-
stealing. Seeing that the affair was regular enough,
however astounding, the Staff had nothing to do
but submit, and proceeded with his captor to the
police court. The Bench was sitting—all, strange
to say, with the exception of one, being opposition
• ’ s-R The Staff was charged With taking and using.
U T tent to sfcea l> a ff 1- ey horse the property
of W. J. Seacombe, of Willy Nilly station. The
accused denied it ; the horse was one he had
ridden in from his friend’s station. At least, he
said so on seeing it, but although it certainly
appeared to be the same horse, it had the Willy
IS illy bx-and on it. He had come in early and left
the horse as usual at the stable of the Post-office
Hotel, to be taken back by one of the station
hands, according to the ostler’s evidence, and what
inferaalwitohcmfti had been and changed it into a
Willy Nxlly horse ?
By this time the lawyer had arrived, and was
defying the bench to proceed with the case; prov-
ing to them that they could have summoned his
client for illegally using, but that issuing a
warrant for horse-stealing was illegal, and that
they wouJd have to pay heavy damages— to all of
which the Bench turned a deaf ear. Seacombe’s
overseer swore to the horse, so did the ostler.
■Robinson himself admitted that he had ridden a
grey horse over, but at the moment he had no
evidence to offer in defence. The Bench had an
earnest discussion, then the friendly J.P. and one
of the opposition left the Court, evidently differing
from the conclusion arrived at by the others. Old
Lisle, as chairman, to the blank astonishment of
everybody, committed the prisoner for trial on a
charge of horse-stealing, bail being refused.
The lawyer retired foaming to the nearest pub.,
where he held forth for two hours on the unalien-
able rights of British subjects and the glorious
palladium of British law.
Borman and one of the leading storekeepers dis-
patched a joint telegram to the member for the
district calling on him to raise Cain, the prose-
cuting party retired to lunch, and the Staff was
locked up. The scheme was a fairly good one ;
even though the Staff could not be convicted of
horse-stealing at his trial, ho would have to wait
in prison for it, and as there was no convenience
for keeping prisoners in the local lock-up, he wou’d
bo dispatched to the nearest town. Then they
would have Forman alone and crush him.
That night, unfortunately for the plan, old Lisle
drank champagne and talked. He asserted several
times to residents in the town that he would shift
the blank-blank scribbler if he lost his billet for it.
His friends got him to bed, but what he said was
remembered. The manager of the station where
Robinson had stopped could not remember seeing
him actually start, but he swore that to the best
of his belief ho rode a grey horse belonging to the
station identical in appearance with the Willy
Nilly horse, but, of course, with a different brand.
The member eagerly commenced to raise a very
■storm in head-quarters, and altogether the oppo i-
tion felt they had gone too far. Instructions were
received from the department to release Robinson
on bail, and the lawyer took a shower-bath every
half-hour to sober himself up.
Old Lisle sat on the bench with bloodshot eyes,
glaring at the accused when he appeared with his
two friends to sign the bail-bonds.
*’ Stop a minute ! : ’ said Robinson, “ I must sign
in my own name. Everyone knows that Robinson
is not my name—it’s Lisle, the same as that man
who has just tried to make a convict of me. I
have the misfortune to be his sou.’’
“You villain! you liar!” gasped the old man.
“My son ran away long ago and died.”
“ He ran away at fourteen : ran away from your
cruelty, and has been knocking about the work!
ever since ; but he’s not dead, for he’s here.”- The
young man unbuttoned his wristband and bared
his wrist, showing a white scar almost encircling
it. “Look here,”- he went on, amidst an awed
silence,_ “Do you remember, just a year after my
mother’s death, tying me up with a piece of
fencing-wire, to give me a flogging, while I
struggled so that I cut my wrist to the bone ?
There’s the mark, you affectionate father.”
The old man sa'd nothing. Everyone who
looked at him could see the truth of what they
had heard in his face. He gasped for breath, and
the doctor, who was in court, ran to him. “ He’s
got a fit,” he said, as they carried him out, and it
was one he never rallied from, for he died without
recovering consciousness next morning.
The affair was hushed up, for although Forman
fought hard to induce young Lisle to prosecute for
conspiracy, he refused. The explanation was
simple enough : noticing the similarity of the two
horses, the Willy-Nilly overseer paid a tracker to
ndein immediately after Lisle, change horses un-
observed in the stable-yard, and ride back on
Lisle’s mount. Information was then at once
laid and the arrest followed.

partners have, for a wonder, made money.

Dear Bulletin, —Many years ago. whilst
digging on the N.Z. West Coast, 1 chanted to be
mates with a litt’e red-headed Irishman, nick-
named ‘‘The Quaker” from his habit of “ theej
ing and “ thouing.” For instance, he would sa'
“ Friend, wilt thou obleegc me wid a loight.” II
had been some time in Philadelphia, and had
there acquired the habit. Well, the “ bhoys
tyere going to have a big night. The Hibernia’. 1 ,
Society were holding a banquet, and “The Quaker
was in a terrible state, for not having joined the
society he was debarred from attending. “Be
gob, friend, ’ said he to me, “if I only had a
green sash I d try me luck.” “ How "do you
mean ?’ said I. “ Why, if I marched up to the
dhure, bquld-loike, wid a green sash on, mtbbe
they d iiivcr ask me if I was a mimber or not.”
1 suddenly remembered that I bad a Forester's
sasli in my box, and the thought struck me to
play a joke on " The Quaker." So, going to tin-
box, I produced the sash arid asked “ how will this
do?’ “Friend,” said lie, “thou hast a sash,’
looking at it admiringly, “ Yes, and if it's any
use to you you can wear it,” I replied—At the
saiue time placing it round his neck. It was of
bright green, and his eyes lighted up with pride.
“But, friend,” he said, catching sight of the gold
letters, A.U.F., upon it, “ what do these mean?”
I his was a poser, and I paused a moment to con-
sider ere replying. But a happy thought came,
and drawing him close to me 1 said mysteriously,
“ Don't you know?” “Xay, friend.” “Whisper,”
said I ‘‘ Amerienn- Order of Fenians.'' He drew
back-, looked hard at me, and then silently grasped
my hand. He knew I had been in America and
never doubted for a moment that I was one of
the Order. He went off to the banquet in high
spirits, and I followed at a distance. At the door
he was stopped, but drawing one of the members
aside a wlr'spered conversation took place, “The
Quaker” frequently tapping the sash with his
hands, and to my surprise, he was allowed to walk
boldly into the hall. He told me next day that he
was the hero of the night, and to this day he be-
lieves in the American “Order- of Fenians.” and
that I am one of them.— Buster.

“The Apostle of Prohibition.”
THE REV. L. M. ISITT, OF
MAORILAND. ,
THE EIGHT FOR TEMPERANCE.
The Rev. L. M. Isitt, a Maoriland temper-
ance captain, who in recent vigorous campaigna
has earned the titular distinction of The Apostle
of Prohibition,” is in Sydney on his way to the
General Wesleyan Conference about to he held at
Adelaide . . . and in conversation with a
Daily Telegraph reporter, he laid out the history
of the Maoriland temperance movement on a
rapid sketch plan scale -
“ Then you are evidently looking forward to a
big political temperance fight in Maoriland .
“Yes ; at the first opportunity.”
“ Did the women’s vote assist temperance
“Immensely,” Mr. Isitt said, “and from his
own point of view, Mr. Seddon never made a
bigger blunder than when he allowed female
franchise to become law, for sooner or later
women’s influence, it is generally agreed, will give
the prohibition party absolute victory.

“OUR BROTHER BOER.”
This is the sort of thing that Joe Chamberlain is getting by the carlad from all over the "Empire" by cable:-"At last night's meeting of Burwood Council the Mayor moved: 'That
the Burwood Council, having heard with great satisfaction of the declaration of peace, has great pleasure in welcoming the Boer population of South Africa into the aspirations and liberties which
we as British subjects enjoy; and that this resolution be conveged to the Boer leaders through Lord Milner.’ Now that peace had been declared it should be recognised that the Boers were British
subjects, and they should sympathise with them, inasmuch as they had suffered the loss of their country."

NEW SOUTH WALES’ OLD MAN OF THE SEA.

General Debilitation,
A CASE IN PYRMONT.
A Permanent Recuperation.
The Case of Mr. W. H. ATKINS.
(BY our reporter.)
VVhat an easy matter it is for a benevo-
lent being to diffuse pleasure and gladness
around him. In order to do so it is only
necessary to consider what means are pos-
sessed to lighten the burdens of our fellow-
men and to help in whatever direction the
may dictate. It is evid-nt that
William Henry Atkins, of No. 211
Crown-road, Pjrmont, shares in this
opinion, for he said in reply to a question
put by our reporter : .
“Of course, I will give you any informa-
tion you require, as the knowledge I gained
may be turned to good account by some
poor sufferer in need of good advice. It
has always been my motto to-help those in
distress, and I think 1 can do so by letting
humanity know about the remarkable ex-
perience I bad. I think that worry was at
the back of all my troubles, for after an in-
cident which pi ieved me greatly, I fell into
bad health. I did n- t care about anything
ts eat, siinp’y because I had no appetite.
The most tasty morsels imaginable failed to
tempt me as a rule, although I had to force
myself to take some nourishment when I
felt that I could not hold out any longer.
Not only was my appetite bad, but I ab-
stained from eating because of the pains
which afterwards appeared. My stomach
always got full of wind, which shifted about
from side lo side, and left cramping gains
in all directions, and heavy pains affected
my chest. Sometimes I felt as if the
breath was bring crushed out of me, the
oppression was s > efreat, and I naturally felt
deeply concerned about it, as chest com-
plaints are so r'mis in their consequences.
As my food was not doing me any good I
lost strergth lapidly, and soon I dropped
into that languid state of indifference to
even thing which is so disastrous to every
business man’s career. I felt as if I did
not care how things went., and the morbid-
ness of my spirits quite precluded me from
thinking about anything pleasant. Haras-
sed as I was by depressing headaches, and
with my eyes dim and feeling as if they
were swollen, no wonder that I lost all in-
terest in life, for the average man does not
wish to live unless he is contented and at
ease.”
“But your lot was not so hard to bear
when night came, for then, I suppose, you
obtained relief in sleep ? ” remarked Mr.
Atkins’ interrogator.
“ Don’t you believe it; if anything, my
nights were more intolerable than the days,
as I could not succeed in getting anything
like a night’s rest. Certainly, I used to
doze off from time to time, but the sleep
was not refreshing, because of the intrusion
of repulsive dreams, and when I got up I
felt as weary as if I had l een awake all
night. I could hardly stand the bitter taste
which was in my mouth every morning, and
the unhealthy condition of my stomach
could be detected by the fur on my tongue;
hut what I regretted more than all else was
the quick and painful throbbing of my heart.
When I laid down I felt that organ shaking
inside in a way that caused me much alarm,
so that, with every particle of strength
being gradually eaten away by my com-
plaints, there was nothing in my condition
to assist me in entertaining hopes of a re-
covery. The least exertion brought on a
feeling of faintness, and when 1 stood up I
used to get quite giddy, as if everything
was on the move. All this I put down to
my extreme weakness, which was also re-
sponsible for the annoying aches in my legs
and loins From some cause or other my
arms were also intensely painful, and if ever
a nervo"? system was wrecked it was mine
On the least provocation I became excited
and irritable, while the trembling of my
nerves served to increase the general misery
of my existence. My body was greatly de-
nuded of flesh, and I can tell you in all
seriousness that my life was a burden which
I would willingly have cast off at any
moment.”
‘ I bel eve you suffered in this way
several years,” interjected the scribe.
“ During the period of your illness did you
ever enlist the services of a medical man ’ ”
“ Considering that I was lingering, wait-
ing, and hoping for years, I should ra'her
think I did,” replied Mr. Atkins. “ Why,
I consulted dozens of doctors, yet my suffer-
ings grew worse, and I may also state that
I have taken scores of medicines which were
procured at stores and chemists’ shops. It
would have been far better if I had kept
the money in my pocket, for all but one of the
medicines were of no service to me. The
only remedy which suited my complaints
was Clements Tonic, and this was recom-
mended to me by a man living in Harris-
street, who had used it, and knew what it
could do. After taking two bottles of
Clements Tonic I felt much better, and was
able to get about with much more freedom.
I went to a chemist to get some more, but
he put ine off by saying he could give me
something better, and pointed out ilia
difference in the size of the bottles, so,
foolishly enough, I bought his medicine in-
stead of Clements Tonic, and in a few days
I was as bad as ever. Then I insisted on
having Clements Tonic, and again I im-
proved under its influence, so that there was
no doubt about its being the best medicine
in the market. I would rather have one
dose of Clements Tonic than a barrelful of
any other medicine, for it proved its supe-
riority in every possible way. The first
thing it did was to make me eat and sleep,
and I was glad of the respite from my
afflictions which I had when resting. Be-
fore long a feeling of animation spread right
through my system, and I then shook off
the yoke of depression which had clouded
my past few years, as I felt assured that
Clements Tonic would pull me through. In
course of time the pains arising from indi-
gestion were quelled; the nauseous taste
left my mouth, and my head was free from
aches. Some of my doctors raid my liver
was diseased, while others said my stomach
was extremely weak; but if they had seen
me after a few weeks’ use of Clements
Tonic they would not have known me. My
stomach could then digest and retain any
kind of food, and my liver symptoms were
non-existent. The shaking of my nerves
was promptly checked by Clements Tonic,
and the regulating and strengthening effects
of that medicine on my system generally
were really extraordinary. Every ache and
pain yielded to the pacifying influences of
Clements Tonic, and I am heartily thank-
ful to say that by its exclusive use my
health w’as re-established. I have lived in
this house for the past 17 years, and all the
neighbours know that Clements Tonic cured
me ; but for the benefit of those who are
unaware of these facts you may publieh
them in any form you like-”
STATUTORY DECLARATION,
I, William Hknry Atkins, of 211 Crown-road,
Pvrmonb, in the State of New South Wales, Coni*
monwealth of Australia, do solemnly and
sincerely declare that I have carefully read
the annexed document, consisting of four
folios and consecutively numbered from one
to four, and that it contains and is a true and
faithful account of my illness and cure by Clement*
Tonic, and also contains my full permission to publish
in any way my statements—which 1 give volun-
tarily, without. receiving any payment; and 1 make
this solemn declaration conscientiously believing t e
same to be true, and by virtue of the provisions ot
the Oaths Act, 1900.

Pbice 6d.
PEACE ON EARTH, GOOD WILL TOWARD MEN.
(A Christmas Carol by the Nations.)
The orchestra of Christmas-tide appears
But once in each recurring year of life.
It plays a tune, at best, of doubts and fears
Concerning bills, and the eternal strife
Of creditors and their dejected prey.
All the performers virtuously talk
Of Charity — they're doing it to-day
Wherever Wealth and Pauperism walk.
N.s.w.
As in the past we sing of Love and Peace
While Jap and Chow hiss words of litter hate;
While Turks slit Christian throats in ancient Greece;
And Ireland strafes the stranger in its gate.
* * * *
This should have been the gayest Christmas Day
The harassed human race has ever seen :
In point of fact, it is in every way
The same old Festival it’s always been.
D.

degree of Doctor of Laws upon the Hon.
Wilfrid Laurier (Premier of Canada). Sir
George Turner (Premier of Victoria), Mr. R.
J. Seddon (Premier of New-Zealand), Sir
Edward Braddon (Premier of Tasmania),
Sir John. Eorrest (Premier of West Aus-
tralia), Chief Justice Way, of South Aus-
tralia, and Mr. H. Escombe, Attorney-!
General c-f Natal.

The Public Orator, Mr. J. E. Saudys, in pre-
senting them, eulogised each Premier
separately in a Latin address.

Recruiting for the Commonwealth Public Service, which has been suspended in recent years, will probably be resumed at an early date. The Public Service

The Bulletin
Vol. 66—No. 3386
Wednesday, January 3, 1945
ENOCH ARDEN CURTIN RETURNS.
He, shaking his grey head pathetically,
Repeated muttering “cast away and lost":
Again in deeper inward whispers "lost."
That which he better might have shunned he saw;
Francis, the slighted suitor of old times,
Stout, rosy, with his babe across his knees.
And Enoch would have knelt, but that his knees
Were feeble, so that falling prone he dug
His fingers into the wet earth, and prayed.

ELASTIC SIDES.
“The Soviet is striving for peace.”— Communist paper.
He picks his marks, does Comrade Joe,
Who rules the far-flung Russian land.
While Gaul and Briton fight the foe,
He aims at peace—on either hand.

Voi. 11-No. 577.
SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 1891.
Price, 6d.
UNCLEAN LEGISLATORS.
“ When commenting recently upon the position in which the O’Shea
disclosures placed Mr. Parnell we expressed satisfaction at the giowth
of a public opinion which refused to accept public sen ices, however
eminent, in eondoneraent of criminal personal conduct. . . . And
public opinion is perfectly right. .... The public verdict in the
cases of Dilke and Parnell emphatically assorts that morality must in
future be as essential to public life as ability, and that the absence of
the one cannot be compensated for by the presence of the other. Ihe
strong public sentiment which in England lately has been pronouncing
inexorable ostracism against transgressors ,of tie moral code is based
on an increased understanding of .ethical morality,. The feeling which
underlies it is not only abhorrence of criminality per se, but a right
apprehension of the fact that one who is guilty of private transgression
cannot be trusted with the conscientious discharge of public duties.
. . , . It is a pretty safe maxim that whoever will deal selfishly
and dishonestly with his fellow-men ?is individuals will do the tame
with them as a whole when the opportunity presents itself. To place
in positions of supreme trust as law-makers and custodians of public
finances men who cannot in .their own personal affairs present a clean
record is about the same as to choose bank-managers from among
known pickpockets The doors of Parliament should stand
firmly closed against the trickster whose career has led him to them
through a course of dishonest a,nd dubious actions . . . and to the
foul and lecherous creature whose domestic conduct is a blot and a dis-
grace upon the society which his presence pollutes. • • • • We are
not so short of men or of manhood in N.S. Wales as to be forced to
seek law-makers in the ranks of hypocritical . . . adulterers. The
people must insist more than they have yet done upon getting repre-
sentatives conduct is able to bear daylight upon it in every par-
ticular either in or out of Parliament. _ We want honest and trust-
worthy men to make our laws, not salacious reprobates .... or
unscrupulous scoundrels.” — Sydney Ministerial Organ, 2Gth Feb.,
1891.
THE STRAIGHT TIP.
PARRES (reading Sydney D. T. leader); “Quite right. My word, we must put all such people out of Parliament."

THE NEW ECONOMIST.
“For six months or so Treasurer Joseph Cook has been telling Australia how he loves economy, and all the public servants shuddered to think of wrath and retrenchment.
The mountain labored and brought forth a mouse. Briefly, the estimated expenditure of the year is £64,604,458, as against last year’s. £64,624,087. In all those millions the
economy amounts to £19,629. There will be no added taxation. The accumulated surplus, however, will be eaten into to the extent of £2,817,108. Eighteen months more of such
economy, and the whole of the surplus will have disappeared.”— SUN.
MISS AUSTRALIA: “You haven’t given my horse much chance. I thought you were going to make it easier for him in his next race.”
HANDICAPPER JOE: “Well, haven’t I? Think of the extra pounds and pounds I might have ordered him to carry, arid didn’t. Isn’t that generosity?”

Sydney.
Dear Sir, —I enclose cheque for one pound with
sixpence added for exchange, and for same will
you please send me Bulletin weekly for a year, •
starting from next issue of same. If the staff are
still lamenting over the £1 6s. perhaps it. will
cheer them up a little to know someone has given
one pound to have the privilege of reading the
Bulletin weekly for one year instead of going to
the patriotic fund ; even the office cat may smile
again.
Yours faithfully,
A. S. B. COBB.
Grabine,
Mount McDonald

"On Sunday afternoon Cardinal Moran referred to the wave of depression which, he said, they all regretted had swept over their own and the neighbouring provinces.

spread like some dread epidemic throughout the length and land, and he would rejoice to see some crusade started winch would have the effect of checking its
growth and finally rooting it out altogether."

A COLD TIME.
“England has had the coldest and bleakest Christmas within memory. Several people were frozen to death. Following the thaw, part of London has been inundated
by the overflowing Thames, and 17 lives were lost in Westminster. Great damage has been done to property and unemployment has been intensified.”

THE NEW COMER.
All the British battleships have now left the waters of Eastern Asia. Since the Japanese naval victory there is no need of them there.— News Item.
JOHN BALL : “I am taking all my battleships from these waters. This is your new guardian. I hope you’ll be fond of one another."

NUMBER
OF THE
BULLETIN
Yol. 7-No. 360.
SATURDAY, DECEMBER -25, 1880.
Frio®,, €kl.
AT CHRISTMAS
BY V.J.D.
WTHE DREAMER.
ITHIN the Austral Christmas-tide,
Whenas his very heart of heat
The sun poured down, from skies
above,
Upon this South Land of his love,
And low warm winds with languid
feet
Went faintly up and down, and died
There was a dreamer, dreamy-eyed,
Who sate beside the sea and read
That book of song, so passing sweet,
The Poet of the Red Rose writ;
So all men marvel, reading it,
That song can live and Chaucer dead.
And even as he paused and sighed—
For alf the perished goodlihead
Of those green years of old, deep sleep'
Fell on him, and so, dreaming-wise,
He saw the ghosts of days arise
That long ago were drowned deep
Down in Lethean waters dead.
Of old time, tales by gray, fjddssung
and said,
Thus was his strange dream formed an 3
fashionM.
THE DREAM.
A King «*.te on a throne of wrought-red gold
tri h groat room whose four fair walls were hung
V Ith rarest hangings, drooping fold on fold
From roof to rush-strewn floor, where shield?
were dung
In shining heaps, with helmets raven-winged,
And spears which many a King's head had un-
kinged.
A fierce fire blazed on the broad hearth, and
threw
Long 11. es of fitful flame on shield and sword,
And lit up now a maiden’s eyes of blue.
And nov the wild eyes of a warrior lord :
The wind without moaned like a soul astray
In the gray dusk of r,hat December day.
THE KING.
The King upraised the bowl to bearded mouth.
But, stopping suddenly, cried, “Lords, this wine.
Is like to b'ood of men we slew in South
Sun-lands, w - hen our sharp prows cut through
the brine
* Last Mead month. Take away the wassail-bowl,
And hear the thought that works within my soul I*
« “Fa r lords lam aweary of the wars,
Aweary of this heaping-un of s ain.
And spilth of blood for Odin’s sake and Thor’s, jj
The gods have both the glory and the gain ; j
Their temples gleam wPh gifts of gold our hands
Wrung from the feeble folk of far-off lands,
" Wh le we, war-worn and gaunt, come home to
yearn £
Forever for the foam of the salt sea ; t
And our own little land and homesteads spurn |
st thought of the strange palaces that be
Beyond them. lam old and battle-scarred,
And serve no more the gods of Asagard.”
Kre ever the King’s words were fairly sped |
A voice cried from the du3k, ‘ The Gods are |
dead,' c
And o’er the threshold of the garth there stepped ;
A wonderful white maid whose tresses swept 9
In golden glory to her girdlest-ead. "
And as through rings of mail-clad men she passed*
Great fear fell 01 them, and each eye shamefast N
Looked down, well-knowing that the end had a

The music of her \ oice died out, ftnd 10.

“ The old goda are well done with, being dead,

Were dark and deathful ; but this fair new god
Is white of hands, and pure and pitying,

THE CAROL.
“ Born in a little stead
Was the Lord Christ,
When the red leaves fell dead
Tn the fiords iced ;
Stars sang and moon of Him,
Scalds sing a rune of Him l
“ Wise men from far-off lands
Came there and bare
Frankincense in their hands,
Red gold and myrrh ;
Kings ki: ted the nhoon of Him
Scalds sing a rune of Him !
“ Thus was He born, and thus
Lowly lived Fie,
Dyiiig for sins of ns
On the cross-tree ;
Bitter the noon of Him.,
Scalds sing a rune of Him 1
“ He who this song of Him
Remembereth
Need not fear in the dim
Day after death.
Blessed the boon of Him,
Scalds sing a rune of Him ! ’’
The carol ceased : the hush so deep
That upon all men sate like sleep
With bitter words was broken through
By a grim-bearded Berserk, who
Knew nought of this new God, the king
Would give his lords for - womaning
Of all the warmen, “ Strike,” he said-,
"The battle-song of Thor instead,
That led us over fields of war
In days gone by. Sing, scald, of Thor 1”
The grey-haired scald struck the harp-strings
To sing the song of the sea-kings ;
But as he touched each wild war-key
The strings cried out In agony.
As if they knew no song could bring
Help to the old faiths tottering.
Then thrice he tried the song to raise
Of Odin and the olden days ;
But ever as the harp-strings rung
The sword-song died upon his tongue,
And softly as the falling snow
This song from his pale lips did flew.

NO PROTESTANTISM IN BUSINESS.
SPOOKESMAN: “We are all Protestant workmen, sir; mostly ironfounders and such like; and seeing that you were a cordial supporter of the
Protestant Defence Association, and were in the iron trade, we thought you might get us some work.”
PROTESTANT DEFENCE MAN : “Well, I can’t. I import most of my iron work from the Romish idolators in Belgium, and when we get the.
tariff abolished, I’ll get still more from them. Besides, I’m arranging a large contract with some cheap Papists in Boheinia. You'll
have to get stone-breaking to do.”

NO ROOM FOR THE FUTURE CHILDREN OF AUSTRALIA.
Merivale, chairman of Sydney Chamber of Commerce, urges that because the infant nation of Australia hasn’t yet fully occupied the Northern
Territory it should be handed over to niggers. This picture represents Merivale’s own house. When he was newly married, and the children
hadn’t yet begun to arrive, he really only required about four rooms of his mansion. So, on his own principle, he doubtless invited Chinese and
Hindus to permanently occupy the rest of the premises. According to Merivale's theory it is foolish and unpatriotic to keen any space for
the children who are to come.

At a special meeting of the executive of the Freetrade and Land Values League it was unanimously decided that the secretary should write to all Federal candidates for New
South Wales, requesting an answer to the following questions:-
1. Are you in favor of reducing the cost of living by abolishing Customs and Excise taxes now imposed upon food, clothing, raw materials and tools of industry?
2. In e vent of the tariff being re-opened, will you vote consistently to enlarge the free list, and, if that fails, in any case tor the lowest proposed tax?

Mr. Charles Carter told the Burton-street
Baptist meeting last night of a marvellous
answer to prayer he had experienced. The
society he belonged to in Melbourne had had an
overdraft of £2l. he knew that by the Lime
tho next meeting came round it would he
doubled. Ho made it a matter of prayer, and
asked tho Lord for £lOO. But the money did
not come. A tew days before the meettog his
faith drooped, add he prayed "Lord, l, don't aaa
for the hundred now, £ut do send uS the twenty-
four and wipe off ouroverdraft." The Monday of
the meeting came, and he watched for the post-
man. but still there was ao cheque. Four o'clock
in the afternoon came, and the committee began
to gather. His faith began to droop, but Jutt
as the meeting was about to commence a letter
was handed him. "Dear Sir.” It read. "En-
closed please find cheque for £lOO for the
funds of the Evangelisation Society as a tbauk
offering from the Arm which we trust will be
the means of spreading tho gospel and thus
bringing blessing to others. Yours very truly,
William Crosby and Co" (Applause! “That
was lovely, wasn't It?” Mr. Carter. "I
ao pratso the Lord, it came Just In the nick
of time as If the Lord had said 'You asked for
that hundred aud you ought not to have dropped
to twenty-four. 1 " Mr. Carter la nresldent of
the Baptist Union of Victoria.
If prayer could be relied on In
business it would be precious
handy. Imagine negotiatin’ overdrafts by faith instead of the
clumsy old-fashioned way of lodgin’ securities!
The other day old Hop sees the above
piece in the Sydney D.T. Always will-
in’ to try new methods (specially
labor-savin’ ones) he said. says he s
•‘i’ll'try what Providence can do
in my line ” ; so he knelt down in
front of his drawin’-bored. with
some blank paper nailed to it.
and prayed that the Lord
would fill it up with high-
class pictorial hnmor for
this week’s Bullytlo.
f a Prime Minister
I could wipe out a deficit
I without increasin' the'
f burden of taxation, or
resortin’ to such low-
down methods as This here f
Then he changed his things
and went off to the boling-
green.
By-and-bye, the Editor he conics Into
the Art Department In a great scot and
says: “ Look ’ere; the printers Is
waitin' for that front page. Where in
i Is old Mop ? ”
« He’s playing boles and trust-
in’ In the Lord,” 1 say s.
Bishops might even compose
special prayers “to be used ”
by Good=Man Candidates, thus
saving election expenses, and
the humiliation to Labor candidates of having, to appear
on the stump in evenin’ clothes. Q
Then I explained how
that cartoon had been
let out to higher
I Powers, and Woodn’t
it be blasphemy
for me to inter-
fere ? “ Well, if that page isn’t in by
2 o’clock, I’ll” Here the Editor
swore so much, my faith began to
waver.
Well, though It was 8-Hour
Oay, I got busy at the 11th
hour, and done the serious of
pictures you are now admirin’
A 3 Think what a boon it
would be to the labor-
ing classes? Rockchoppers,
for instance.
After all, methinks, ’twould be awfully
nice
If faith without works would cut any
ice.

union to its old position the Government will take steps to make them.

The Bulletin
Vol. 67—No. 3474
Wednesday, September 11, 1946
SCENE FROM “THE MERCHANT OF CANBERRA,”
“Is your name Chifley?” “Chifley is my name.”
“A pound of this Australian’s flesh is yours—
Caucus decrees it and the Statute gives it.
Let mercy season justice.” “By my soul,
There is no power in the tongue of man
To alter me. I stay here on my bond.”
“You shall have justice, more than you desire.
You shall have nothing but the penalty.”

LOOKING BACKWARD—
Like one that on a lonesome road
Doth walk in fear and dread,
And, halving once turned round, walks on
And turns no more his head,
Because he knows a frightful fiend
Doth close behind him tread.
"One looks back at the past for lessons that will help one to face the problems of the next decade."— Federal Labor-leader Curtin at the Victorian A.L.P. conference.

A MEETING.
1st.--The White G. H. Reid (with dog), whose Government demanded that the Australian mail boats should have white stokers exclusively, and who adopted
the educational test now in use by the Australian Government for the exclusion of colored immigrants from N.S.W. (This gentleman is temporarily dead.)
2nd.—The Black Reid (with dog), who now declares that the exclusion of colored labor from the stokeholes of Australian mail boats is an outrage.
3rd.—The Yellow Reid (with dog), who now alleges that to keep out colored aliens by an education test is a public disgrace.
Various other colored Reids (with dogs) may arrive at any moment.

PiilCE CD.
HIS ESKIMO HONOR.
Judge Ewing, of Tasmania, just back from holding an inquiry at Darwin, says the North is “the place of lost souls.” He adds that it is the hottest spot on
earth, and that (though it is none of his business) he must include some remarks about the White Australia question in Ins report
HIS HONOR (home again, and interviewed by HOBART ICEBERG): “It’s a terrible, terrible place. There isn’t a snowball or a glacier in the whole
country, and I found my snow-shoes quite useless. When I asked for whale-oil at the best hotel the savages had never even heard of it.
They’re a brownish people up there, not blue with the cold like us, and I don’t like the look of them."

THE IMPORTING DISEASE AND THE MELBOURNE WATER SHORTAGE.
MELBOURNE CITIZEN: "Let's see! Melbourne wanted a better water supply. I lost my job at the pipe-factory because it was our policy to import the
pipes, even if they cost more than our own. We borrowed the money abroad to pay for the imported pipes. I was taxed to pay interest on the loan.
The pipes didn't come because of the war. We're all taxed to pay for our share of the war. Now I have neither a job nor a wash!"

A 'DAY OF THANKSGIVING.
The bounteous rainfall since the “Day of
Humiliation and Prayer” has led to a mo-
tion in the Anglican Synod now sitting
in the Chapter House. Bathurst-street.
Canon Moreton, haying obtained leave, yes-
terday afternoon moved that “This Synod
wishes to place on record an expression of
its grateful sense of the goodness of Al-
mighty God in sending in our time of great
necessity, an abundant rain over the co-
lony, and desires to regard the same as a
direct answer to prayer.” /

OLD GHOSTS AT A MODERN FEAST.
“The renort of the NSW Pubric Accounts Committee discloses that during last year the Lang Government paid away £4,698,295 without Parliamentary authority.”
“In 1899 on account of a payment of £300 to reimburse J. C. Neild for expenses incurred in Europe, the Reid Government was turned out of office, not because the
payment was not considered justified, but because it was made before Parliamentary authority had been obtained.”
GHOST OF JAWBONE NEILD (talking to the ghost of George Reid): “Five millions in the petty cash box! They
certainly do things differently in these days!”

THE FAVORITE FALLS DOWN.

PREMIER REID’S UNDELIVERED SPEECH .-ILLUSTRATED BY
“ HOP.”
The Bulletin
Registered at the General Post Office, Sydney , for Transmission by Post as a Newspaper.
Vol. 19.—N0. 962.
SATURDAY, JULY 23, 1898.
Prick, 6d.
To the Electors of King Division.
The following is the unpublished and un-
delivered address of Premier George H.
Reid to the electors of King division,
Sydney. The Bulletin has been waiting
to hear Reid deliver it, but at last its
patience has given out, so it puts on an
eye-glass, and takes a large chew of toffee
these accessories are required to “ make-up”
the character, in the language of the stage—
and delivers the address itself:
To The Electors op King Division. —
Gentlemen : I appear before you for themanyth
time. In 1887, when this electorate was called
"I appear before you.”
East Sydney and had four members, you kindly
put me second on the poll (below Burdekin)
with 4108 votes—2262 votes ahead of the de-
feated candidate. By 1891 my popularity had
so far increased that I just got in as the last of
the four members, being badly licked by
M'Millan, Barton and Varney Parkes. I
got 2946 votes, and was just 686 ahead of the
defeated candidate. In 1894, when the King
was a single electorate, I got 819 votes, and
had a majority of 469. In 1895, I had 610
votes, and scraped in by a majority of only
132. I represent 610 out of 2174 electors.
This isn’t why I believe in majority-rule as
applied to Federation.
I have been a great success at dropping
things. In fact, I claim to be the champion
dropper of Australasia. Among other things
which I have first promised and then dropped
are the State Bank, State note issue, the
The champion dropper.
resumption of big estates
for closer settlement,
State Land Bank, Local
Government, Reform of
the Legislative Council,
Freetrade (I am going
now to secure a few votes
by protecting the New
South Wales sugar in-
dustry, after swearing to
exterminate it), absen-
tee tax, graduated land
tax, the fiscal referen-
dum, and the raising of
loans locally. Which is
a good deal of drop-
ping to do in four years.
My only two conspicuously democratic
measures were the Navigation Bill and the
Shops and Factories Bill. The nominee Council
destroyed about all the good that was in both of
them. It also threw out my Stamp and Pro-
bate duties. Although you elected me in 1895
on my assurance that I was going to wipe the
Wiping the floor.
floor with the Council, that floor remains un-
wiped to this day. I have now announced (1)
that I am going to fight this election also on
the question of Council Reform, and (2) that I
have a great esteem for the unreformed Coun-
cil, and am going to carefully preserve the
nominee principle.
I promised at the late lamented Jubilee that
I wouldn’t go to England
or take a title. Naturally
I did both.
* • »
I am the author of the
famous £333,000 surplus of
1896. The published Govern-
ment Statistics show a defi-
cit of £448,000 that year,
but my surplus was quite
legal, for I passed a law
by which nearly £BOO,OOO
of the year’s expenditure
was not the year’s expendi-
ture at all. If I had passed
My Jubilee title.
a bigger law I could have made the surplus
.£3,000,000 instead of .£333,000.
The accumulated deficit is just about where
I found it. Also, I have just finished the
biggest year’s borrowing
since ’9l, and the big-
gest year’s loan expendi-
ture since ’93.
I was a bitter provin-
cialist till 1894, when it
became necessary to dish
Parkes. At that date
I turned Federationist,
and have remained so
ever since. Any one who
wants to see a real
Federationist is request-
ed to walk round me
twice and consider the
spectacle.
I invited the other
My financial state-
ment.
provinces to Federate
with New South Wales. Every invitation to
Federate has, so far, come from New South
Wales. That is why Jack Want and I always
throw mud at the other provinces and insinuate
Mud.
that it is they who are intensely anxious to
federate with us from the lowest and most
mercenary motives. This sort of thing keeps
the Federal spirit alive. Jack Want didn’t
call the other provinces “wolves.” I heard
him do it.
I agreed to the insertion of the 50,000 mini-
mum in the Enabling Bill, just to give Pro-
vincialism a good start. When it was proposed
to increase the minimum I suggested 80,000,
and said I would accept it, and voted partly
for it and partly against it. If I had wanted
to keep faith with the other provinces, and had
made it a Government question, and had told
my party to vote against the 80,000 minimum,
of course it would have been defeated ; but I
didn’t. lam an unusual kind of Premier, and
you never know what I am going to do.
When the Federal Bill was before the Council
my esteemed colleague, Jack Want, declared
that he was a provincialist, and the “arch-
destroying angel of Federation.” Also he de-
scribed Federation as “ a hydra-headed monster
basking in its constitu-
tionalbeastliness in this
bright and sunny land.”
I have taken Mr. Want
back into the Ministry
as a guarantee of our
joint sincerity in seek-
ing Federation. We
make a really beautiful
pair —we do indeed.
Hooray !
* * *
At the Federal Con-
vention I voted for the
three-fifths majority on
a joint sitting of the
two Houses (it was my
valued colleague, Car-
ruthers, who proposed
it), for equal represen-
tation of the States in
the Senate, and for leav-
ing the division of the
He had kept Jack Want's
wig in a soft place.
surplus to the Federal .
Parliament. I didn’t even call for a division
on the bounties question, or on the right of the
Senate to suggest amendments in money bills.
I voted against federating the debts and rail-
ways, and I didn’t once ask for a guarantee of
the territorial integrity of the States.
Now, I am against equal State representation
in the Senate, against the three-fifths majority,
the bounties arrangement, the power of the
Senate to suggest amendments in money bills,
and the leaving of the division of the surplus
to the Federal Parliament. Also, I demand a
guarantee of the territorial integrity of the
States, and I leant to federate the debts and
railways. In fact, I am against every im-
portant point that I supported, and I am howl-
ing for everything that I previously denounced.
Since writing the above I have begun to wobble
again, and I don’t really know whether I want
to federate the debts and the railways or not.
As I have beautifully expressed it, “ the last
word has not yet been spoken” with regard to
the financial arrangements. Therefore my
Federal amendment proposals are as clear as
mud. That is why I jeer at Barton for not
making his Federal programme more definite.
* • * *
When I came back from the Convention I
at once started to denounce the Bill because of
the things I had done my level best to put in
it, and because of its lack of the things I had
helped to keep out. I told the people to vote
against it. I voted for it my-
self. lam built that way.
I am a quaint and remark-
able person all round.
There were 72.000 votes for
the Bill and 66,000 against
it, but by reason of the 80,000
minimum, which I cordially
accepted and voted sometimes
for and sometimes against,
the minority wins. That is
why I am now hollering for
majority rule. When this
discrepancy is pointed out I
simply say that 7*,000 isn’t
a majority of the 295,000
electors. The 610 voters who
Quaint and re-
markable.
return me for King Division aren’t a majority
of the 2174 electors either, but that is quite
a different thing.
My friend and colleague, Jack Want, an-
nounced, before the Federal vote was taken,
that, if the Bill was carried, he would still do
his uttermost to block it in Parliament here
and also'in England. In fact, he was going to
damn the majority. He also
hollers for majority-rule now.
• * •
I am particularly strong
now in demanding that the
Referendum shall be inserted
in the Bill. When Wise pro-
posed the Referendum in the
Convention, I voted against
it. Wise is a beastly Aus-
tralian native.
When the Bill was lost,
The Attorney-
General’s gy-
rations.
on account of my 80,000
minimum, I, on behalf of the minority, and
in the name of majority-rule, asked Turner,
Braddon and Kingston to hold a Conference at
once, before the New South Wales general
election came off, to consider amendments.
Braddon refused, which conduct I have since
denounced as discourteous. I called Braddon
a lunatic, or something like that, at the Gon-
vention. That wasn’t discourteous. Besides,
he is a refined, frail, grey-headed old gentle-
man in bad health. Kingston also refused. I
didn’t call him any bad names in the Conven-
tion. He is a large, healthy, middle-aged per-
son who loves fighting, and he has a very short
temper. T i j
Turner agreed to the Conference I asked
for, but I took all manner of care that he
didn’t get it. He also asked what amendments
I wanted, but I refused to supply them.
Turner is a beastly lawyer. lam also a
lawyer.
By this arrangement I showed my sweet
reasonableness in asking for a Conference, and
the man who agreed to confer and the people
who didn’t agree to confer were equally left. I
have since denounced Turner for his lack of
sincerity. The fact that I promised to furnish
my list of proposed amendments was sufficient
reason for not doing it. And the fact that I
demanded the Conference before the general
election fully explains why the election is here
now and the Conference isn’t.
* * • *
When Barton was Attorney-General and
tried to put a Federation Bill through Parlia-
ment Want and I both opposed him. That is
why I now sling mud at Barton and accuse
him of making no attempt whatever to help on
Federation.
When Barton decided to contest Bourke he
showed himself a coward for running away
from Sydney. I challenged any of the Federal
leaders to meet me in King Division, and
Barton, much to my surprise and disgust,
accepted the challenge. That also shows that
I never expected YOU!
he is a coward—for running
away from Bourke. I don’t
want to fight big Barton.
I only wanted to fight little
Tom Slattery.
Barton wants to reform
the New South Wales
Council by making it an
elective paid body with no
property qualification and
based on manhood suffrage
—just like the proposed
Federal Senate. Thatproves
him to be a wretched Con-
servative. I propose to
keep it an unpaid House
of Nominees. That shows
that I am the only genuine
Liberal now on the market.
The other reasons why I am a Liberal are
that I voted against the Referendum at the
Convention, and against the rule of the
majority in the joint Federal House, and in
favor of giving Tasmania, with 170,000 people,
the same voice in the Senate as New South
Wales with 1,300,000. Also, I dropped the
State Bank and State note-issue and other
things for the same reason. Another proof of
my Liberalism is that I hold a 66,000 anti-
Federal minority should boss a 72,000 Federal
majority.
* * * *
With regard to purely New South Wales
politics, I promise Local Government and a few
other things, just as I did before, and mv pro-
mise is just as valuable as it was then. lam a
strong believer in the Referendum, which is the
reason why I broke my promise to have one on
the fiscal question. And lam the same reliable
Freetrader as of old, in consequence of which
I am going to protect the sugar duty and I
levy £1,300,000 per head in Customs duties —a
larger sum in proportion to population than is
levied in such Protectionist countries as France
or Germany, and nearly twice as much per
head as is levied in the United States.
I am the head of a just and GoD-fearing
Government. My Government is a whale for
justice. That is why we refuse Suffield a
hearing, despite the strongest doubts as to the
fairness of his conviction.
Lastly, I have assured you that if you re-elect
me you will find me the Same Old George. In
other words, the same old Shuffler ; the same
old No-Yes ; same old Janus and Facing-Both-
Ways; same old two-headed curiosity on a
Same old George!
fence. And, under these conditions, I present
you with my amended Federal programme
(which I haven’t submitted to the other pro-
vinces, lest they should reply that they aren’t
having any, and then I couldn’t very well go
to the country on it) ; also my choice assort-
ment of broken promises. My other six or
eight amended Federal programmes will be
out shortly. If you re-elect me I don’t
know exactly what I will do, for I never
have known ; I have merely wobbled on the
spur of the moment. But at least you will find
me a fearless administrator, just as I was when
I let the Council reject my Probate Duties Bill,
and destroy all the good points in my Navigation
Bill and Shops and Factories Bill, after which
I didn’t demolish the Council, but grovelled
to it, and promised to preserve its nominee
character intact. Therefore I look back on my
steadily-diminishing majority of past years, and
wobble before you with confidence. And my
confidence is just the same kind of thing as my
old promise to abolish the unemployed in 24
hours, and my fiscal Referendum, and the other
things,
Here endeth (for want of space—not want
of matter) the unissued manifesto which the
same old George Reid— always different—
didn’t present to the electors of King
Division.

IDJI.IT BIT IDAY
WE PUBLISH EVIDENCE LIKE THIS,
The Case of Mr. A. LYES.
(for tub “standard.”)
The requirements of the Australian popu-
lace can only be arrived at by reference to
the statistics which are compiled at vaiious
periods, and as evidence is necessary for the
purpose of gauging popular opinion, it may
here be interesting to listen to Mr. Albert
Lyes, of No. 7 Frazer-street, Leichhardt
When living in the North Coast dis-
trict,” said Mr. Lyes, “ [ experienced a
vast amount of trouble with my liver and
kidneys, the consequence being that I was
put to a lot of inconvenience owing to the
acute pains across the small of my back.
As I had heavy work to do at the time, my
afflictions came as a great hardship, more so
if there was any lifting to be done, when my
back pains were intensified to a degree that
I could scarcely endure.”
Reporter: “ Were you much affected in
any other part? ”
Mr. Lyes : “ It would be quicker for me
to tell you where I was not affected, for I
had aches and pains all over tne. There
was a cold, painful sensation in the spine
which felt as if somebody had shot a ball of
ice along my back, and that horrible shoot-
ing pain extended right to my eyes, which
also gave me the impression of being
swollen. I was sluggish, drowsy, and had
no energy whatever, the only tiling I felt
fit for being to lie down—it did not matter
where. It is a serious matter for a married
man to get into that condition, but I held
out as long as I could, and then I had
to give in, for all the grit was taken out
of me. Being without any appetite, which
had been on the wane for a long time, the
chances of stopping a further leakage of my
vitality were very remote, and as I could not
sleep at all well at nights, there was no
doubt that I was in a very grave state. With
my tongue covered with a nasty substance
and a vile taste in my mouth, there is
nothing remarkable in the fact that I could
not enjoy any food, and in the natural
course of events I got a long way thinner
than I ought to have done. I was tor-
mented with very severe headaches which
made me feel so gloomy and wretched that
there seemed to be nothing in the world
worth living for, and with my weakness
daily increasing, my limbs ached so persis-
tently that I could nob even take a walk in
comfort. Pal pi ration of the heart and dizzi-
ness always followed any exertion, my
heart being particularly bad. It used to
make a thumping sound like the noise from
a horse’s hoof heard in the distance, and
many an anxious hour have I passed in
thinking what might be wrong with that
organ. Like most people who suffer like
this for the first time, I constdted a
doctor, who said that my liver and kidneys
were diseased. He wrote a prescription,
which I had made up, and said I would
have to keep as quiet as possible, and not
exert myself any more than was absolutely
necessary.”
Reporter: “How did you feel after
taking his medicine?”
Mr. Lyes: “Just about the same as
before, and when I saw it was only so much
waste to take any more I dropped it- olf.
The oppression in my chest and the flatu-
lence in my stomach were still there, and
the urine remained of a cloudy and scanty
nature, so what was the use of throwing
any more money away I thought ? Besides”
my nervous system was completely out of
order, as any kind of noise had a startling
effect which kept my nerves at extreme
tension, as if they had been suddenly un-
hinged, and then, again, I felt agitated and
irritable at the slightest provocation. The
long-continuance of these sufferings had
made me very morose and low-spirited, for
there were others to think of besides my-
self; but, thank goodness! that trying
ordeal is all over now, and it is not likely
to bo repeated, because I discovered a
remedy which cured my ailments then, and
i am sure it could do so again if ever I
needed it.”
Reporter: “ May I learn what the remedy
was ? ” J
Mi. Lyes : “I have no desire to keep the
matter secret, because I might do other
poor sufferers a good turn by letting you
know. It was Clements Tonic—a medicine
that I had been reading about—that made
a new man of me, and I always regard it as
my only friend amongst all medicines. I
had only taken a couple of bottles of
Clements lonic when I felt ever so much
better. In fact, the change was so great
that I could scarcely believe it myself
especially as I had lost confidence in
physics generally. But Clements Tonic
asserted itself as something uncommonly
good by rapidly giving me a desire for food,
and in the matter of making me sleep well
thought it a most marvellous medicine.
Ihe health-giving properties of Clements
-Lome were not confined to those improve-
ments, a 3 it amended the defects in my
internal organs which had gone against the
digestion of my food, and by those means
the pains in my chest and shoulders were
relieved. The fermentation of my food
was done away with in like manner, so that
I was getting the full benefit of my meals,
and how well I knew it ! for the return of
my strength was quite noticeable. I no
longer desired to lie about in a state of
careless languor, for Clements Tonic gave
me the energy and ambition to do some
work, which was becoming easier to per-
form each day, because the pains in my
back were less troublesome as time moved
on. My heart gave me no occasion to
worry myself, as it was beating with a
tegular pulsation, and with the departure
of my headaches my sight became so clear
that I could sit down and read for hours
without the least inconvenience. I was
greatly pleased with Clements Tonic for
the effect it had on my nervous system,
lor it invigorated my nerves so thoroughly
that they became perfectly steady, while
such a thing as becoming excited or annoyed
over trifling incidents did not happen. A
good indication to go by as to the efficacy of
Clements lonic was the entire removal of
my deranged kidney symptoms, and it was
then that I was altogether free from pain.”
Reporter : “ Did you stop taking your
medicine immediately that happened ? ”
Mr. Lyes: “Not exactly, for I wanted
to be quite sure that all disease was effaced,
so I took another couple of bottles of
Clements lonic, and when they were
finished it was not necessary to take any
moie, as I was as strong and thoroughly
restoied as I could wish to be. It is several
years ago since ( lements Tonic put an end
to my sufferings, yet my work has never
since interfered with my health—a fact
which shows that Clements Tonic made me
as sound as a bell ; and if these statements
are likely to i e perused by others, you may
publish them as you like.”

Price, 6d,
THE LOGIC OF BRITISH CAPITAL.
“The leading Westralian mining co.’s contemplate making a big reduction in wages. In a speech made by Lord Castledown at a meeting of the West Australian Goldfields, Limited, last month,
here is another straw which shows how the wind is blowing. He said: ‘ The labor, so difficult a problem in Africa, one which has been the real cause of all the bloody fights now going on in
Mashonaland, will undoubtedly be solved in West Australia on different and more satisfactory lines. It may be that the white man will remain the sole factor in the labor question there, or it is
possible that some of the large laboring races may be imported from neighboring shores to work under the superintendence of the colonists.”— DAILY PAPER.
J, BULL: “My troubles about ‘ Australia for the Australians !’ Wot I says is, ‘ Australia for dividends on British capital.' Nigger labor means big dividends. If you weren’t
born a nigger — well, is that the fault of British capital, hey?"

paper, read rather funnily

taken advantage of the attendance of the occu-
pants of the houses visited at church to commit
their depredations.”

MIXED BATHING.
No 1 —“The executive of the Evangelical Council has protested to the
Minister for Education against the open competition of girls in a
swimming carnival at Fitzroy Docks. The members of that body
do not object to, girls competing in swimming competitions, but to
their doing so in the presence of a mixed company.”
No. 2. —“ The Premier is still fishing at Lake Macquarie. He is not expected
to return to Sydney till Thursday.” But he has had to change
his bait.
No. 3—MORE “ MORAL EFFECT."
First Samoan King : “ I see by the papers that Maoriland is sending a con-
tingent to aid the dear old mother country in killing our pigs and
niggers, so we may as well'give in. I don’t know that I care about
being a King, after all ! ”
HiS Rival : “No; it isn’t good enough. Let us become thoroughly civilised,
and offer * contingents ’ ourselves to help exterminate other niggers.
It’s good business.”

one Hebrew Appropriate chorus of judges : “ Fancy,me eating you !

IN THE JUNGLE THAT IS EUROPE.
On thy knees and draw the bow; bid the shrilling arrow go;
In the empty, mocking thicket plunge the spear;
But thy hands are loosed and weak, and the blood has left thy check —
It is Fear, O Little Hunter, it is Fear!
Through the war-gongs of the thunder rings a voice more loud than all—
It is Fear, O Little Hunter, it is Fear!
(With acknowledgments to Kipling.)

THURSDAY, JANUARY 16, 1919.
Wab-time Pkice, Sd.
REFUSE SHOT HERE.
[FOR THE BULLETIN.]
“'When asked if there was not a danger in sending the Kaiser to Holland, Count von Bernstorff replied: ‘Where in hell were we to send him?’”
Now where in hell could this person go?
All gates were shut that we used to know;
He had barred them with weeping and blood and
woe.
The valiant Swiss, on their mountains high,
Looked out with a cold, unkindly eye;
They had suffered much and they well knew why.
The Danes, in the midst of the world’s alarms,
Stood to their guarded posts in arms;
They knew the Prussian in all his charms.
Across the Russian frontier red,
Where his own loud mouth had the tumult bred,
A king must travel without his head.
The gates were barred, not a door was seen;
The sea was not what the sea had been,
Tor mutiny stirred on the submarine.
So they tossed him over the low Dutch wall—
I rayer, bravado and crown and all —
To wait till the dirt-box man should call.
N.S.W.
CURSE O’ MOSES.

LACK OF WORK: ITS REAL CAUSE.
UNEMPLOYED : “Why can’t we get work making some of these things instead of importing them?”
IMPORTER : “No! Australia’s £40,000,000 worth of annual imports are the backbone of its prosperity. Imports are the only true test of a nation’s
greatness. It becomes great by buying things, not by making them. These imports represent the factories you haven’t got, and the
work and wages you haven’t got—and that’s where I come in. Get to relief works!”

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1002.
Price 6d.
SQUARING THE CIRCLE.
George Reid, in a recent Victorian address:
He would warn Protectionists that they need not give any votes to him either in the House or out of it, for the moment he got the power he would make the tariff an honest tariff. He looked
upon protective duties as the downward path which led to poverty and corruption, and as long as he lived he would be squarely against them.
The news that George is going to be honest for the first time in his political existence, and that the man who protected such a wonderful lot of things
when he was a Freetrade Premier in N.S.W., is going to be Squarely against Protection at last, is indeed a staggerer. The physically globular Reid
and the politically crooked Reid are both familiar. The Square Reid would be the last straw. This country can’t stagger under three Reids.

SOME ADVICE TO LITTLE WILLIE.
The Speech at the opening of the N.S.W. Parliament mentioned with joy that the Labor Government had borrowed all the money it needed within the State.
AUNTIE DAILY PAPER: “You must keep on being a good boy, Willie, and always be kind to the nice fat gentleman, who. is really a poor
widow and a lone orphan. And when you do anything for him you mustn’t ask him to pay ; you must be a nice good boy and
ask him to lend you the money, and then you’ll be able to supply him with interest all your life. And he’ll be so glad that in time
he may adopt you for his own little boy.”

THE LIVERPOOL (N.S.W.) “TUBERCLE FARM.”—A MIDNIGHT DEPUTATION.
LEADER OF THE DEPUTATION : “As the most recent death at the institution, I have been asked, JOHN SEE, to introduce to you this deputation of the 1901 and 1902 victims of the N.S. W. Govern-
ment’s Liverpool Tubercle Farm. There are 76 of us killed in 1901, 55 so far in 1902, and we expect a couple more every hour. So we claim this to be a large and influential deputation.
What we wish to point out is that a consumptives hospital that would cure, not kill, would be really a permanent and reproductive work, and might, with much more advantage certainly
than your tombstone to soldiers, be charged to loan votes. The men who get consumption, and are cut off in the prime of life, are often men cf brains, often skilled mechanics Fat politicians
don’t get consumption; but I assure you that some men very useful to the State do. Save them, cure them instead of killing them, and you will have a valuable asset in the shape of an
increased body of taxpayers. It won t cost much—less than a ducal celebration. You will excuse the absence of the usual compliments: Dead men know not how to flatter John See—
What do you mean to do?"

Our'cricket barometer again.-
GOULBURN, Friday.—An inquest was held to-
day on an infant 7 months old, the son of a
laborer named Smith. The evidence showed, that
Smith had been in gaol for three months. He
came out yesterday, and went home drunk.
While he was in gaol his wife had been unable ;
to get sufficient money to keep the family, and i
had collected bottles and rags. She earned in !
this way from 4d to Is 6d a day. The child died ;
from marasmus, the result of insufficient food, i
“The holding^
capacity of a young infant’s stomach is
about one ounce. A lazy, careless nurse
gets a feeding bottle, with a tube, so that
she can lay the child down with the artifi-
cial teat in its mouth. She puls half a pint
of the milk preparation into the bottle, and
lets the baby suck away. This keeps it
quiet, but the result is that it overloads its
little stomach and vomits. So the milk is
blamed for being bad, when, if properly
used, it was quite good.” It is very pro-
bable that merely through ignorance many
children are done to death in this way to
save whose lives their mothers or nurses
would grudge no amount of care or trou-
ble.

make some special effort to mitigate the trials
of the clergy. The Easter offerings are
generally devoted to the clergy, and it is
further suggested that where naoney gifts are

substituted.”
No reasonable offering refused !

In the Grip of La Grippe
MANY COMPLICATIONS LEFT BEHIND.
—wwr w——i— ——
All Banished and Health Restored
by CLEMENTS TONIC.
The Case of Mr J BARTLETT.
(BY A SYDNEY REPORTER.)
It is to the interest of this country that
all citizens should be so educated that they
may become a self-reliant and prosperous
people, and to put this idea into practical
effect a reporter was commissioned to bung
before the community a mat er here d< alt
with by Mr. James Baitlett, of No. 5
Patten’s Buildings, Kent-street, Sydney.
“In the time of a great epidemic,” said
Mr. Bartlett, “ when influenza was ram-
pant in Sydney, I was one of the many
who failed to elude that terrible disease.”
“ Were you in danger of meeting with
serious consequences? ” asked the w. iter.
“ There was every likelihood that I
would never get well again, as I was n a
frightfully low stato for many months.
Matters went so badly with me that I
thought I was fighting a hopeless fight
against an overwhelming force, and as I
1 was laid up for weeks, and could not do a
stroke of work for se\en months, I think I
had good cause to form that opinion. I got
so thin and ghastly white that, everynudy
thought I was going into consumption, be-
sides getting awfully weak into the bar-
gain. The pains in my head were enough
to run away with one’s senses, being of that
heavy, depressing nature which makes the
victim feel as if there is only care and
sorrow in the world, It was not the in-
fluenza itself that I had to regret so much
as the effects it left behind, for my system
seemed so upside down that there was not
a sound part about me. My limbs were so
racked with aches that if I walked a few
yards I had to sit down and rest for the
purpose of easing the pain, but another
reason why I could not go far wit.iout
taking a spell was because I used to turn
very giddy. Through that cause I nearly
fell down stairs several times, so
that I was almost afraid to move in case
of meeting with an accident. I wondered
what was the good of living in such misery,
for I had no energy, no pleasure, no any-
thing that was worth having. For weeks
and weeks I could not get any sleep, and
there was a feeling in my eyes as if they had
swelled up. A dark haze was visible at
every turn, my sight being so bad that I
could scarcely see. and if I wanted to get
anything for myself I had to grope about
aslf it were dark. I could not hear very
distinctly either, owing to a strange drum-
ming in my ears, so that I was not much
use to anybody. Indeed, I was a nuisance
to myself, and would like to have been out
of the way of the persecuting pains which
came to the small of my back and almost
paralysed me whenever I stooped. This,
together with the thickness of my urine,
told me that my kidneys were disordered,
and I was afierwards told so by the doctors
whom I was treated by, with the additional
information that my liver was also dis-
eased.”
“ Did they give you any medicine ? ”
“Of course they did, and I was never
behind hand in taking it, as my enforced
absence from work meant a great loss to
me, and I wanted to get belter. But, some-
how, my condition remained stationary.
When I examined my tongue it was al-
ways furred and rough, while my mouth
had a foul taste as if I had been drinking.
Not a morsel of food could I enjoy, but I
am not one to give in till I am fairly beaten,
and I used to make myself eat ; but it
would have been better if I had spared my-
self the trouble, as everything seemed to
decay in the stomach, and give rise to ex-
cessive torture in the form of windy spasms.
My chest also felt as if a pier-e of lead had
1-dged there for the purpose of stopping my
breath, and there was no relief to be got
till I vomited everything up again. The
weakness of my stomach was so advanced
that I could not keep my food down, so
that accounts for my feebleness and the loss
of flesh I sustained There was also some-
thing wrong with my heart, which palpi-
fated as if I had been indulging in some ex-
cessive exercise, and With my nerves all
gone I was completely wrecked from every
point of view. A twitching pain below my
neck irritated me, but for that matter I
was always in an irritable mood, even the
sound of voices raised in laughter being
sufficient to annoy mo; but I was so
des, erate and desp ndent that I did not
know what to do with myself. In any
short stretches of sleep I got there flashed
an awful picture upon my vision, and when
I woke up I could not help "thinking that
something I dreaded would surely happen,
although I recognised that death would
have been preferable to any more suffer-
ing”
“ Why did you not try a change of
medicine ? ”
“If I had not done so I would not be
here to-day. as I w as sinking very fast after
the long and torturing captivity in the
hanls of my diseases, when a fellow work-
man prompted me to try ( foments Tonic.
It was not till I carried out his advice that
the influenza was beaten, and now, after a
long and convincing experience, I am sure
there is no medicine on earth tike Clements
Tonic, for after taking a eotipte of bottles I
was feeling a new interest in existence.
Trie improvement was then so marked that
I ventuted to hope that a possibility still
existed that I w’ould yet recover, and by
closely pursuing my latest course of treat-
ment my heartklt hopes were gratified. I
stated on the right track with a slight
appetite, which came through using
Clements Tonic, and which that medicine
continued to increase. Then my liver be-
gan to work more regularly, a fact which
afforded great relief in several ways. For
instance, my headaches slackened- off, and
the sickly taste left my mouth, besides hav-
ing full use of my eyes in consequence of the
disappearance of the haziness before them.
The pains in my bac and shoulders were
lighter than b fore, and I had no trouble in
breathing, as my chest was quite free from
oppression. A feefing of vigour crept
through my system through the medium of
Clements Tonic, and I was gaining in flesh
already, which showed that my food w'as
digesting well. I marvelled at the rapidity
with which my vomiting troubles were
stopped, while the action of Clements r l onic
on my nervous system could not be too
highly spoken of. When my liver and
kidneys had been relieved of all symptoms
of disease by Clements Tonic I hardly knew
how to suppress the gladness I felt, es-
pecially as no cause remained for a* xie y
as to the state of my heart, which ceased
palpitating shor ly after flatulence was
remedied.”
“ And now your health is perfect, I
believe 1 ”
“It could n n t be better, for I took
Clements Tonic till I was cured outright,
and for the past three years I hav e scaled
over 13 stone. lam thankful to be able to
give this information, which you can pub-
lish in any way it pleases you.”

Tome; and also contains inv full permis ion to pub-

kingdom.”— Esther , chap. 5, verse 3.
And Queen Esther took King Ahasuerus at his word, and said she would have Australia, and as that country had no army or navy with
which to defend itself it became a Jap dependency, and remains so to this day.— Fragment of Australian Chronicle.

point in one year,’ he said, ‘but we hope to halve the estimated deficiency in the next financial year.’ ”

AUGURED!
“At Trafalgar (Vic.), two swallows circled inside the hall before Mr. Hughes spoke. Looking at the birds, Mr. Hughes said that the ancients watched the movements
of birds, and also the clouds, for auspices, and surely the auspices for him were most happy.” —Daily paper.
HUGHESIUS CAESAR: Augur, by me two swallows have been seen.
Say! What the blinding blazes does it mean?
HEAD OF CAESAR’S NEW AUGUR’S DEPARTMENT: The swallows, Caesar, signify a flight
Northward, in shameful terror of a fight.
Twice have the Plebs your party at the polls
Swallowed, but now, alas! my lore unrolls
Another fate. Hark to your Augur’s word:
The year ’22 will see you get the Bird.
[Augur dismissed and Department abolished.]

METALLIC MUMMIES.
A leading French physician, t)r. Variot, has been demonstrating the possibility of
obtaining metallic mummies of our friends, which may be used either for street decoration
or for household purposes. These onr monts can be prepared in gold, silver, nickel, or
copper, according to fancy and the pocke* and should the idea be adopted there is a great
future for this new branch of electro-plating. To effect the metallising much elaborate
apparatus is required, and the body has to bo previously painted with nitrate of silver to
render it a good electrical conductor. It is stated that .by regulating the deposit all details
of conformation may be retained, while at the same time the image can be made of
suffic’°nt thickness to withstand external blows.

OATS IN THE SMOKING ROOM.
When the s.s. Orion left Devonport (Tas.) for wayside ports and Melbourne.the holds were crammed with cargo, and the men had to stand on the hatches to
force them down. There was cargo on the main deck and on the upper deck (and at Burnie, later on, 253 bags of chaff were also put on the upper deck).
There were 25 bags or oats in the smoking room. — Evidence given at inquest.
And the Orion went out and was never heard of again. Also, it seems that no one was responsible.
